talk.start.para: âOrder! Pursuant to an order agreed to earlier this week, I call on Senator Greig to make his first speech and I remind senators of the usual conventions.

âI spent my youth on the coast at Lancelin, where my parents were involved in the crayfishing industry. I recall with affection the many times I worked as a deckhand on my father's cray boat, miles out to sea, in the wee hours of the morning, surrounded by rotting cow hocks and fish heads, and crashing face first into strong headwinds. Some might say this was good preparation for a career in politics. It was there, growing up on the windswept coast north of Perth during the late 1970s and early 1980s, that I developed my love of the sea and of the coastal sands and bushlands which hug the Western Australian coastline, a region rich in the history of the early exploration by the Dutch.

speech.para: Growing up in Lancelin introduced me to the wonders of natural history and instilled in me a deep respect for native flora and fauna. My early years were in some ways mirrored by the life of one of my favourite authors, Gerald Durrell, who as a child grew up on the sun-drenched shores of Corfu in Greece. He later wrote with great clarity and humour about his love of wildlife and the need to protect and preserve it.

In later years, as a student activist I campaigned in defence of free education and in opposition to tertiary fees. I also fought strongly for compulsory student unionism, and am proud of the role that the Democrats have played in defending this principle, once again, from attack. At one point during my student days, I could be found waist-deep in muddy swamp water trying to stop a road bypass being constructed through the Farrington wetlands at the southern edge of Murdoch campus. However, the road went through, as roads so often do, and it was a road that eventually brought me all the way to Canberra.

However, I would be painting an incomplete picture if I did not detail the most profound aspect of that journey. That is the fact that, since the age of 12, I have known I am gay. This has profoundly influenced my life and given me personal insight into intolerance, prejudice and the hatred that I might not otherwise have experienced. Equally, it has made me determined to stand against this and to fight against all unjust laws by confronting law and opinion makers with the reality of their intolerance.

As a young person coming to terms with my sexuality, I found it to be an alienating and lonely experience. Schools ignore their gay and lesbian students for fear of being seen to promote homosexuality. But, of course, a person's sexuality is innate. It cannot be taught and it is not contagious. As a consequence of this conspiracy of silence, gay and lesbian youth live in an environment of denial and rejection, with no support, counselling, validation, or role models. And then we wonder why it is that up to one-third of all young people who attempt suicide do so because of the anguish or uncertainty over their sexuality.

Lesbian and gay youth are a normal and healthy part of the diverse human family. They need to know that and to know that they are not alone. As the author of Tales of the City, Armistead Maupin, said more succinctly:

I wish someone older than me, and wiser than me, had taken me aside and said: You're all right kid. You can grow up to be a doctor or a teacher just like anyone else. You are not sick or crazy or evil. Most of all though, you can love and be loved without hating yourself for it.

It came as a shock to me to learn in 1989 that I was a criminal. And in the views of the Western Australian parliament I remain a criminal, because there is no statute of limitation on this type of prosecution. Prior to 1989, all gay men in Western Australia were considered criminals and faced 14 years in prison for consenting sex in private. Little has changed and, although this law has partly been repealed, gay males in my home state under the age of 21âthe highest consent age in the worldâare still regarded as criminals. These laws are worse than any that exist in Western or Eastern Europeâwith the exception of Romania.

In WA, gay men are still being arrested, still being charged, still being fined and still being imprisoned under laws that do not apply to heterosexual peopleâlaws similar to those which saw Oscar Wilde imprisoned in Reading Jail more than 100 years ago. While anti-gay laws also exist in New South Wales and the Northern Territory, they are most draconian in WA. Additionally, WA holds the dubious distinction of being the only state where discrimination against gay and lesbian people remains legal. We can be refused employment, accommodation and the provision of goods and services. This happens frequently and with impunity. There is no state or Commonwealth redress. Federal human rights laws exclude us.

As a nation, Australia maintains appalling laws against gay and lesbian people. We live under a regime of apartheid. It is an apartheid not based on the colour of our skin, but on the colour of our sexuality. Homophobia is nothing less than sexual racism. But homosexuality is not a behaviour to be regulated. It is an identity to be respected. We are people, first and foremost. We work, we have lives, we love and have relationships. We are family.

Yet, despite being citizens, voters and taxpayers, lesbian and gay Australians do not have the same rightsâor in many cases have no rightsâto those things in life that heterosexual people take for granted. As a gay man, I can be denied access to a hospital to visit my partner if he is sick or injuredâbecause I am not considered next of kin. If I should die, my partner has no legal claim to my superannuation death benefit, despite the fact that I have nominated him as my beneficiary. I cannot claim my partner as a dependant or split our incomes for taxation purposes and, if we should separate, there is no legal mechanism to ensure fair and reasonable property settlementâwe are denied access to the Family Court. And so it is for all same sex couples.

These complications are even more pronounced for the many gay and lesbian families raising children. It may come as a surprise to the Senate that many gay men do in fact have children and that about 30 per cent of lesbian couples either have or plan to have children. Despite this, some people still promote arguments and laws in opposition to what is the reality of many people's lives. But the fact remains that, no matter how many obstacles you place in front of women trying to have children, those women who really want children will have children, as is their right. Heterosexual people do not have a monopoly on good child rearing practices. It is those people who really want children who make the best parents.

The systemic denial of our relationships is evident even here in the Senate. I am required to fill out the senators' register of interests, including notation of any assets and shares belonging to my `spouse or de facto partner'. And yet as recently as May of last year, the Senate determined that these definitions must apply only to heterosexual relationships. Lesbian and gay MPs are precluded from registering their partner's interests. When I inquired as to what I should do in relation to Keith, my partner of 13 years, it was suggested to me that I may want to simply comply with the spirit of the register and to provide Keith's details anyway. As a matter of principle, I cannot.

Gay and lesbian people fighting for compensation and superannuation death benefits find that the spirit of those acts cannot be applied to same sex relationships. And so it is with unfair stamp duty payments and other taxation imposts, property settlement, family payments and spousal recognition within the defence forces and Public Service. Gay and lesbian people seeking to be regarded as next of kin for hospital visits or funeral arrangements can find that the spirit of those acts cannot be applied to them, and the immigration process for same sex couples applies differently and to our disadvantage. The spirit does not apply here either. No, the spirit of Commonwealth legislation towards same sex relationships is decidedly mean spirited. We are excluded.

I give notice that I will move to amend the orders of the Senate relating to spousal definitions in the register to ensure that gay and lesbian MPs will also have the same responsibilities as other members of parliament. The legal recognition of same sex relationships is a human rights priority that must be addressed by the Commonwealth. The New South Wales government has already done this. The Queensland government has indicated it is set to follow, and the Tasmanian government is looking at doing so following the sweeping changes to gay and lesbian law reform that have occurred in the island state.

In his victory speech in 1998, Prime Minister Howard spoke of the need for a more caring and tolerant Australia. At their national conference in Hobart two years ago, the Australian Labor Party unanimously passed a motion recognising the need for equality and justice for gay men and lesbians. If these parties are serious about this, as the Democrats are, then now is the time for them to act. The Democrat Sexuality Discrimination Bill currently before the Senate will remove all discrimination from Commonwealth legislation as it currently applies to the sexuality of all Australians. Further, it will impose national antidiscrimination laws on the basis of sexuality or gender status, and make it unlawful to incite hatred on the same grounds. It deserves cross-party support.

Discrimination against gay and lesbian people is as morally repugnant as racism or anti-Semitism. As a nation we have fallen behind comparable jurisdictions, such as New Zealand, Canada and South Africa, in terms of protecting the human rights of homosexual people. For as long as governments condone this apartheid, they are creating the social and political environment that leads to harassment and violence towards gay and lesbian people. While parliaments continue to deny our relationships, deem us to be criminals, and render us to be second-class citizens without legal protections, then some people will take this as their cue to continue to treat us badly.

Australian research shows that almost half of all gay and lesbian people report some form of discrimination or harassment at work, including sackings. Roughly 30 per cent of lesbian and gay people experience harassment at school. And, worst of all, 70 per cent of gay and lesbian people report being verbally abused, threatened or bashed in a public place.

I wish to take a moment now to briefly tell the story of a young man called Matthew Shepherd. Matthew was a slightly built 21-year-old student in Wyoming in the United States. About a year ago he was lured from a campus bar by two men. They drove him to a remote area outside the town of Laramie, where they viciously beat him. As he lay there bleeding, begging for his life, he was bound to a fence and left in near freezing temperatures to die. He had been beaten so badly that his limp body, when found, was at first thought to be a scarecrow. His attackers had stolen his shoes and robbed his apartment. After being struck in the head 18 times with the butt of a hand gun, he remained in a coma for five days without regaining consciousness, before dying. Matthew Shepherd was murdered because he was gay.

Before anyone here is tempted to think that this could only happen in America, I remind the Senate that no fewer than 30 men have been bashed to death in Sydney since 1990 simply because they were gay or presumed to be so. This violence does not occur in a vacuum, it is not spontaneous. Hatred of this kind takes years to mature within societies. It is nurtured through a culture of invisibility and fear towards gay and lesbian people and the neglect and indifference of parliaments. Each time a piece of legislation comes before the parliament and touches on human rights and human relationships but excludes gay and lesbian people and denies our relationships, it perpetuates this culture of invisibility. Each time a public figure or religious speaker denounces our existence or seeks to justify our differential treatment, it perpetuates this culture of fear. As Justice Michael Kirby said on this topic recently, `The game of shame is over.'

I stand here today, on this first day of spring, and on the dawn of a new century, as a representative of the last generation of gay and lesbian people who will tolerate the injustices of the past being carried into the future. To the thousands of lesbian, gay, bisexual and transgendered citizens who know the pain of abuse and discrimination and to those who have been unjustly arrested and jailed, I pledge my support and the support of my party.

Throughout my 10 years as a human rights activist, I was inspired by the dedication and tenacity of small groups of people fighting for change against overwhelming odds. These groups have very few resources, other than a passion for justice and a strong desire for change. At times these groups face opposition so fierce it can lead to violence, as we have seen recently in the forests of Western Australia, and it is deeply personal. Yet it is these tiny community groups which change community attitudes, which in turn change laws.

I salute the Tasmanian Gay and Lesbian Rights Group which, through a 10-year campaign, brought about the repeal of offensive anti-gay laws in that state, a state which now leads the world in sexuality education programs, and leads the nation with antidiscrimination laws. And I offer my respects to Rodney Croome and Nick Toonan, the public faces of that movement. Their legacy is a United Nations resolution reaffirming the human rights of all gay and lesbian citizens, a resolution which has shone a light into some of the darkest corners of the world and which can now be built on. I also salute the Gay and Lesbian Equality group in my home state which, after 11 years of fighting, is on the brink of achieving change. Its legacy is the shift in community attitudes it has brought about though reasoned arguments, truth and persistence.

Senator Tchen, in his first speech, spoke of the generational change taking place in parliament. Specifically, he referred to the election of himself, a Chinese born Australian, and of my colleague Senator Ridgeway, an indigenous Australian, as indicative of this generational change. I agree, but I would go further and add that the election to the Australian parliament of a gay and lesbian rights advocate is also indicative of this generational change. It is also indicative of the maturity of the Australian Democrats as a party of representation and reform. Let us hope that as a nation we enter the new millennium a society not simply of greater tolerance but of greater acceptance.

Finally, I offer my sincere thanks to the many thousands of Western Australian citizens who voted for me, and in doing so have asked me to represent them and their interests in the Senate through the prism of Democrats' policy and philosophy. I accept that challenge.

In closing, I want to express grateful thanks to my parents, both of whom worked hard to provide better opportunities for their children, and to my partner, Keith, who taught me that the personal is political. Keith, never short of an opinion, knows exactly what is wrong with the world and what it is that politicians need to do to fix itâbut then he is a cab driver, so you have got to expect that. I also express thanks to Lucy, for her unconditional love, but then she is a kelpie, so you have got to expect that too; to John, a fellow traveller who shares this journey with me; to Sophia, for teaching me that everything changes; to June, for pushing; to Melinda, for being there; to the Democrats, for their trust; to the Western Australian gay and lesbian community for its support; and to the late Chris Carter, a gay man and founding member of the Australian Democrats, who showed the way.

talk.start.para: âI plan today to continue my contribution to the policy debate on rural and regional Australia. I would like to begin by repeating what I said in the chamber last week, and that is that the big challenge in rural and regional Australia, particularly given the opening up of the Australian economy to the world, is that as we move towards deregulation and globalisation it is up to government at all levelsâfederal, state and localâto come up with effective strategies to assist the bush to survive in this new global environment.

speech.para: The debate that we face on this is really between two points of view. One is to focus on the major centres and let the smaller centres just downsize naturally, without any assistanceâin other words, perhaps recognising the imperatives of a global economy and saying, `Well, the more efficient way to run things is from the bigger centres, places like Dubbo, Wagga, Tamworth and Lismore, and the smaller centres will naturally fade away.' The other view is to empower all communities, including the smaller centres, to actually leverage themselves up under local leadership to find their niche in this new marketplace. Later on in this speech today I want to go into a number of examples, a number of cameos, of small centres which in a totally economic rationalist world you would think would decline and die but have shown that they have the ability to survive and, with a little bit of government assistance and with a little bit of leadership in the local area, to find their particular niche in the world.

I favour very much this second broad approach. The reality is that the larger centres, the Waggas, the Bathursts, the Tamworths and the Lismores, will survive anyway. They will survive against the Sydneys, the Melbournes and the Brisbanes because they have enough critical mass to grow. The thing that greatly concerns me, and I bring it to the attention of the Senate today, is that they are getting a lot of their growth and taking a lot of their strength from the surrounding countryside. I used to work for a number of years in Wagga in south-west New South Wales. If you look around Wagga, you see that what is happening is that the smaller centres are the ones that struggle as Wagga acts as a magnet to commerce. These are places like Junee, for example, 20 kilometres away, Cootamundra, Henty, The Rock, Mangoplah and Cookardiniaâby the way, they had the greatest football team in the Riverina at the time; Mangoplah-Cookardinia United used to beat Wagga. So there is a great lot of spirit in some of these little centres. These are the ones that actually suffer as the big towns take up an increasing part of the economic framework of growth of a particular region.

So let us look at what has happened in recent times with the centralisation of commerce, with modern communications and technologies, and with modern transport meansâpeople having greater access to cars. If you are like one of our senators who lives outside Junee, if you wanted to go shopping you might go to Junee or you might bypass that and go to Wagga, 20 kilometres away. So we have to actually build incentives into the system and help local leadership develop strategies so people are going to want to stay in local areas.

Certainly, they may go to big centres like Wagga to do a lot of their business. But we must give the smaller centres the opportunity to capture as much of that as possible so that not only the people who are actually in the little towns but also the people in the countryside will have a greater opportunity to stay in those centres. That will happen if we give this sort of assistance.

If we were not to move on strategies that would assist the small towns to survive, we would face, in terms of the whole landscape of Australia, a fairly bleak future. We would have a greatly depopulated landscape. We would have, under the alternative scenario, very few people outside the major centres. We would have rural holdings growing in size and therefore fewer people out on the land and we would have a lot fewer people in the towns that originally used to service those. So I am suggesting that maintaining a structure in rural Australia where we have big thriving centres and also have a series of increasingly thriving towns and villages is a lifestyle in this country which is worth fighting for.

I would like to emphasise the role of government in particular in the survival of these sorts of locations. I want to inform the Senate of the example of a place called Walcha. Walcha is a small area: it has a town population of 1,700 and a population in the surrounding areas of 3,500. It is up on the northern tablelands of New South Wales. It is fairly close to places like Armidale and Tamworth and it is feeling the effects of the competition of those bigger centres as people increasingly move to do their shopping and business in those larger centres. A place like Walcha, which you might think with that number of people will just wither and die, really has the opportunity to fight back and government has a role in helping the Walchas of this world survive. I will give you three examples of government initiatives in the Walcha area that will help bring that about.

The first relates to the major industry surrounding Walcha, which is the timber industry. We have regional forest agreements, and we have spent a lot of time debating them in this parliament in the last two weeks. We have a balance that we still have to get right in this country between conservation and development. We have in the forests surrounding Walcha and in the traditional management practices of the timber industry the opportunity to harvest and to renew those forests in an orderly manner.

But if the state government, which has prime control over the RFA in that area, gets it wrong, what will happen in Walcha will be just what will happen in the Hunter Valley and in many towns, such as Dungog and places like Stroud and Seaham. They will die because there is not enough timber to feed the mill, the mill shuts down, the timber workers do not have a job, all the support industries go out of business and the town declines. So that is a possible future facing Walcha if the state government does not get it right.

Interestingly enough, the federal government has a role in Walcha as well, and it is one which we may not realise. This is why I would like to draw it to the attention of the Senate. In Walcha is a very advanced veterin ary lab. It seems a strange place for this lab to be. It is a family business which has grown over the years and it has an international market for its product. As a matter of fact, most of its market is international because we have set up a regimeâthis must have been a long time agoâwhere the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation actually has a monopoly on some of the services that these people would like to provide. Why? It is a historical overhang which we should probably do something about because, if there are small businesses in country areas that can compete with the CSIRO, why should they not do so? This is a move that this parliament should take some interest in.

The other way in which the parliament has assisted Walcha relates to regional transaction centres, which we are setting up across the country. They are one of the major underpinnings of small country centres that can help them survive. We have seen over the years a wide range of government services disappear. Indeed, I am involved at the moment in a Senate committee inquiry, and its report which we are about to sign offâon unemployment and employment in regional Australiaâhas made it very clear that the government's role can be quite crucial. With regional transaction centres we have the opportunity now to rebuild the infrastructure that has been lost because of a range of government decisions.

In the case of one town, our report actually goes through what government facilities have been lost. When I looked through the list of facilities, I saw they were all state government things which have been shut down. Railways have been shut down as well as hospitals. Withdrawal of police services, the downsizing of the teaching service and a whole range of other things have been done by the state government.

What we have done federally is to come back and put in an underpinning through rural transaction centres. These are centres where people can undertake banking and a whole range of other types of activities that will help people stay in those areas. If you have to constantly drive from the farm, past the town, to the city, which might be 70 kilometres away, and come back, the pressure of living in that sort of isolated environment will drive people from the land in this country. With new technology we have seen the opportunities for that to come back.

We also had a great win for the bush recently in terms of that technology, which will give people in Walcha great heartâand in many other much more remote placesâwhen Telstra last week launched in this parliament its Big Pond advance system, which is a way of communicating in the bush via satellite. Initially terrestrial systems will be used but, where that cuts out, the system will switch to the satellite. In terms of the number of megabits per second, we were talking about normal standards of 64, but this satellite system has a standard of 200 megabits per second. The bandwidth in remote Australia under this system will jump way past what is available in the cities. So let us chalk one up for the bush there.

Through government assisting the development of these sorts of new technologies, people can live in a place like Walcha and carry on their traditional business, but they can also develop, particularly via these new communication technologies, a whole range of other businesses. One of the great things that came out of the partial sale of Telstra is the fact that, under the rural communications infrastructure fund, we put aside moneyâinitially a quarter of a billion dollars and, out of the last sale, more againâto support these sorts of developments and a whole range of little projects out in the bush that would improve communications between people who are living outside the big cities and the people who are in those big cities.

We really need to provide those opportunities further because, if you are running a business that is communications based, you can live in a place like Walcha and, provided you have that link in communications, run whatever your business is out of that area. We have the opportunity in the next 100 years to actually turn around this depopulating development that has occurred right through this century. I have mentioned before A.D. Hope's comment about the parasitic nature of the big cities and the fact that then there was a low population concentration in the country; that has now become lower. With new technology we can switch this right around and help people move out of the big cities to live in these beautiful areas that have a great lifestyle, and that will improve the lifestyle in country Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI have some matters I want to refer to and, if I have time, there are a couple of points that Senator Tierney referred to that I would like to touch upon. There was an interesting article in the English Financial Times on 12 August. The story was headed `Plan to introduce tax breaks for shipowners'. The story was about a plan by the British government to stem the rapid decline in the British merchant fleet. The size of the UK owned fleet has shrunk by two-thirds since 1980, while the numbers of British seafarers has fallen by more than 60 per cent, from 52,000 to just 20,000. The Australian shipping fleet has suffered a similar fate, but its decline has accelerated dramatically since this government came to office in March 1996. But I am afraid that the chances of seeing a story in the Australian Financial Review , with the headline `Government helps Australian shipping industry', are Buckley's and none.

speech.para: The shipping industry, and all those industries and workers who rely on it for their livelihood, may have been heartened by a media release from the former minister for transport, Mr Sharp, on 13 August 1996. Mr Sharp was announcing the establishment of a special shipping reform group to advise him. He said that he was committed to implementing the government's election promise to make Australia's shipping industry internationally competitive. His statements suggested that he had rightly recognised the importance of this industry to the future of the Australian economy. It appeared he was aware that this country boasts the fifth largest marine freight task in the world.

Mr Sharp received a report from his special task force, which was headed by Mr Julian Manser, in March 1997. That report was released in May of the same year. He said that the report proposed a solution to the continuous decline in the merchant shipping fleet. He said there was an opportunity to restore and expand the industry. He said there was an opportunity for future growth and more jobs. He said:
Our commitment is to defend Australian shipping and shipping jobs by placing the industry on a competitive footing for the future.

Mr Sharp was misleading the industry and the Australian community. The government did not move to implement the plan; it only took up the easy options presented by Mr Manser. The tough issuesâthe establishment of a second register and the provision of fiscal support for the Australian shipping industryâwere put off its agenda for another year. It set up yet another task force. It initiated yet another inquiry. It asked for yet another report. This is the second report on shipping reform, and it is now on the desk of the current transport minister, Mr Anderson. It has been there since April.

In contrast to the first report, this is a secret document. Mr Anderson has refused to release it, even to the shipping industry. The reason is obvious. That report exposes the flaws in the government's policy, or lack of it. That report says that Australian shipping is a key export industry in the Australian economy. Despite the rhetoric from Mr Sharp about a future for Australian shipping and despite the successful efforts of Australian shipping to increase its efficiency and cost competitivenessâon tonnes carried per vessel basis, productivity in the Australian registered fleet has increased by 40 per cent since 1991âthe government has opted to condemn the Australian merchant shipping fleet to a slow death. It has progressively increased the number of permits given to foreign vessels to enable them to operate on the Australian coast. It will not assist this industry, as other governments, such as the British government and the governments of Denmark, the Netherlands, Norway and Germany, have done.

The do nothing approach is very much the Anderson way of public administrationâdo nothing and the problem will eventually go away. But in this case so will thousands of jobs and hundreds of millions of dollars of financial benefits for the Australian economy. The effect of the do nothing approach is now showing through. The share of cargo carried by Australian flag vessels into Australian ports as a percentage of deadweight tonnes fell from 9.98 per cent in 1995-96 to just 3.68 per cent in 1997-98. That figure was down further, to 3.29 per cent, in 1998. Under the oversight of the Howard government, the share of cargo shipped out of Australiaâthat is, exportsâhas dropped from 2.42 per cent in 1995-96 to 1.96 per cent in 1997-98. That figure dropped further last calendar year, to 1.91 per cent.

The do nothing approach has also seen the collapse of investment in Australian shipping, and the average age of the Australian shipping fleet has increased as a result. The average age of the Australian shipping fleet was stable per vessel at around eight to nine years for the decade for the 1980s and into the early 1990s. Australia could rightly claim that we had a modern, safe and efficient shipping fleet with highly skilled crews and crewing levels down to OECD average. That average has slipped now to 13 years per vessel.

This government is handing the job of carrying our exports and imports to a Third World shipping fleet with an average vessel age of 18 years and will pay around $1 billion in current account losses for the privilege. Mr Anderson's plan will see our freight carried entirely by flag of convenience vessels with untrained crews, vessels on which even the most basic of safety standards appear to be optional. Over the last 18 months, some 300 of these ships have been detained in Australian ports by the Australian Maritime Safety Authority. They were detained because of serious maintenance problems and equipment and crew deficiencies. On average, one of these ships is detained in Sydney alone every two weeks. The task of trying to ensure that our marine environment is protected and our port safety is maintained is currently difficult. Under the Anderson maritime plan, it will become impossible.

Let me illustrate the problem AMSA faces in making the international fleet accountable. Last April a container ship called Direct Falcon was detained by AMSA because it had communication problems and defective dampers in its engine room. The vessel flew the flag of the Bahamas; it was owned by Maritime Falcon Incorporated and it was managed by Australia New Zealand Direct Line. Four weeks later, the Direct Falcon was back in Australia, but it now flew a Liberian flag, it was now owned by Fourth Nordcap Shipping and it was now managed by Colombia Ship Management. How can this industry be held accountable if the ship's front falls off or if it spills oil all along our coast? This is a regime, and these are the ships, that Mr Anderson is inviting to take over both the coastal and international shipping tasks in this country.

There are two more important consequences of the decision by the Howard government to do away with the Australian merchant shipping fleet. The first relates to the entry of illegal immigrants into this country. The Minister for Justice and Customs, Senator Vanstone, said recently that the great problem authorities face in locating and deporting illegal immigrants is in the major cities. It is very easy to get lost in a city of several million people. The presence of a large foreign shipping fleet operating on the Australian coast for extended periods of time will add significantly to this problem. The current limits on the length of time foreign seafarers are allowed to remain on the Australian coast will have to be abandoned. Deserters are already a problem. Between March 1996 and 30 April this year, some 263 ship deserters were reported to Customs. Only 148 of those deserters were located.

The issue of illegal immigrants has rightly been the subject of some considerable debate in recent times. I asked the Minister for Justice and Customs a question without notice on implications for border controls flowing from the government's plan to end Australian shipping. Surprisingly and disturbingly, she knew nothing about the issue. This is despite the fact that the government had a report that very much went to this matter. Mr Sharp had that report in March of 1997, more than two years ago. Senator Vanstone told me in question time that she would seek advice on this matter. She did. She sought the advice and she provided a written response. In it, she said she could not comment. There has been much talk about professional people smugglers and how best we can deal with the problem, but this government, without the knowledge of the Minister for Justice and Customs, has a plan in place which will facilitate this movement of people into Australia rather than prevent it.

The second consequence relates to our national security. On 25 February 1982, the government of the day established the Australian Shipping Defence Council. The council was set up to promote the partnership between the Australian Defence Organisation and the Australian maritime industry. Its job was to facilitate the provision of effective advice and support to government on maritime issues in the interests of national security. It was there to ensure that the Australian merchant fleet could be mobilised quickly and effectively in the event of an external threat to Australia. Under the Anderson plan, there will be little that councilâit is now called the Maritime Defence Councilâcan do. The reason: there will be no Australian merchant fleet to mobilise. No matter how you look at the approach taken by this government to the management of the Australian shipping taskâwhether it be financial, environmental, security or effective border controlâthe situation is that this policy is a disaster waiting to happen.

I want to say something in relation to the comments made by Senator Tierney earlier today, particularly those comments relating to Walcha in New South Walesâyes, I have heard of Walcha; I have not been there, unfortunately, but I suppose there are a great many places in Australia that I have not had the fortune to visit. He spoke about the effect on Walcha of an RFA entered into by a state government; that Walcha was at the mercy of a state government in relation to the entering into of an RFA. I say to Senator Tierney that, if he had those concerns, he would have supported Labor's amendments to the RFA legislation giving this parliament the opportunity to disallow an RFA that did not properly deal with the matter. But of course he did not do that. I invite Senator Tierney to con sider his actions in the light of his comments today in which he sought to question the role of his state and, thereby, all states in the making of RFAs, and the process that this parliament should enter into in approving the legislation now before it.

Senator Tierney also talked about a veterinary laboratory which produces a product that is exported internationally. Let me say that there is nothing unusual about regional centres being engaged in important manufacturing tasks, particularly those related to the activities of rural and regional Australia. In my state of Tasmania that is not surprising at all. For instance, the opium poppy crop is processed at a place called Westbury in north-eastern Tasmania. Although Westbury would have a population smaller than Walcha, it is an important industry to the state. It is as important and, indeed, as appropriate an operation for Westbury as is the operation for Walcha, and as are a great many other important contributing operations throughout rural and regional Australia. So the opposition is not at all surprisedâas Senator Tierney appeared to beâabout the operations in Walcha. We think there should be more of them.

talk.start.para: âI rise today to speak on the question of the International Year of Older Persons. As I think we are all aware, the year is an opportunity to celebrate the contribution of older Australians in our community and to implement positive initiatives to enhance their quality of life. As a society, we do not value enough the participation of older persons. The International Year of Older Persons is a valuable opportunity to counter some of the negative images portrayed in the media and to promote the positive contribution older people make in a range of areas in our society.

speech.para: I want to raise the opposition's concern about the government letting this opportunity slip away. We are now two-thirds of the way through this International Year of Older Persons and I am receiving many complaints from constituents and aged groups about their disappointment with the progress being made and with the government's response to the year. It is those concerns that I would like to give voice to today.

The disappointment older Australians are expressing is understandable, given that the preparations for the year promised so much. At the outset, I want to give credit to Senator Kay Patterson for her work last year in chairing the Conference for Older Australians. The Conference for Older Australians was established in February 1997 to advise the government on Australia's involvement in the international year. Under Senator Patterson's leadership, the conference held consultations with 350 older Australians across the country. On the basis of that consultation, the conference released its interim report in June 1998 on themes and issues that were identified by older Australians as areas of concern and as areas where positive steps could be taken to make a lasting impact on the lives of older Australians. Yet it appears that the government has simply put the report from the conference on the top shelf and ignored many of the issues and suggestions raised through that consultation with older Australians in the lead-up to the year.

The government's inaction is most apparent in relation to the development of the National Strategy for an Ageing Australia. One of the former ministers for family services announced in November 1997 that the government would develop a national strategy for an ageing Australia. The Department of Family and Community Services web site contains the following statement:

The National Strategy for an Ageing Australia is primarily concerned with developing a proactive response to the emerging issues related to population ageing. This is the Commonwealth Government's key policy response to the International Year for Older Persons.
This is a very laudable objective and one which the opposition supports.

The work of the Conference for Older Australians through 1998 provided a good basis for the development of that strategy. This was noted in an article from ARPA Over 50's Association in June this year titled `Get on with it Minister!' The article notes that on 14 July 1998, following the release of the conference report, the then Minister for Family Services, Warwick Smith, wrote to many organisations advising them on the development of the National Strategy for an Ageing Australia. A ministerial reference group was set up to consult with the Conference for Older Australians to work on the development of the strategy. Nothing much appears to have happened since.

In early May 1999, the current Minister for Aged Care, having been appointed the chair of the new ministerial reference group in February 1999, circulated a background paper on the development of the strategy. The faces in the group were the same as those from the previous year, except for the new minister being made chair. That background paper, launched in May, in the minister's words:
. . . sets out the key policy issues which Australia will face over the coming decades.
I think people were generally disappointed with the quality of that paper but it did provide a background basis for the development of the strategy.

The article by ARPA notes that the four themes identified by the Minister for Health and Aged Care in May 1999 were almost identical to the themes identified by the government in July 1998. It notes that the national strategy remains `a pipe dream' and concludes by calling on the minister to `get on with it' and develop the national strategy for an ageing Australia. That call is even more pressing now, three months on, as we see no sign of anything further being done by the minister to progress the development of the strategy. At the June round of Senate estimates, I queried the department on a timetable for the development of the strategy, and I quote the department's response:

The background paper is not itself a discussion paper but a scene setting paper for the further discussion paper that will be released on a staggered basis throughout the year. At the end of June we will be releasing a paper on healthy ageing. After that we will be releasing a paper on world-class care, another paper on independence and self-provision and a fourth paper on attitudes and lifestyles in the community.
As I indicated, the first paper will be released at the end of June and then monthly thereafter.

I do not know whether I have missed them, but I can find no trace of any of those papers. It is now September and, unless they have been circulated to a very select group, none of those papers have been released. By the department's own account, the first three of these papers should be out in the community generating the discussion necessary for the development of the strategy. Remember, it is a strategy for the ageing of the population to mark and celebrate the International Year of Older Personsâand we are in September. These discussion papers have not even been produced, to the best of my knowledge. Unfortunately, it is now clear that the strategy, which is the government's key response to the year, will not be finalised until well into the year 2000. After announcing the development of the strategy in November 1997, the government's inaction on the issue will mean that older Australians will have to wait until the year after the Year of Older Persons to see what the national strategy for an ageing Australia will look like. I can only echo the call from ARPA and ask the minister to get on with the development of the strategy.

More recently, the minister sent out a letter to members and senators about the Commonwealth's recognition awards for senior Australians. That undated letter arrived in late July/early August and set out the following timetable for the award system: ASAPâform an electorate-wide selection committee; ASAPâcall for nominations; mid-Augustâassess applications for awards; end Augustâmembers present awards; and 3 Septemberâname of outstanding constituent forwarded to the department. This was a scheme whereby each member of the House of Representatives was to recognise 20 older Australians' contributions and to select one to be sent to Canberra to participate in a ceremony. The reality is that many members of parliament did not see this letter until the first week of August, which gave them just three weeks to administer the awards. Many members have expressed to me their concern at their inability to do the program proper justice. They are concerned that they have not been able to give the scheme the sort of attention, publicity and involvement that a serious treatment of the International Year of Older Persons deserves.

Understandably, a number of older Australians have been contacting members' offices and my office to complain about the ridiculously short timetable provided to nominate for the awards, and they are concerned that the value of the awards has been downgraded by the lack of proper organisation. Mr Denys Correll, the Executive Director on the Council of Ageing, has noted the awards have been on the drawing board for some time. He is quoted as saying, `So we are a little disappointed that there is so little time.' I have a letter from the Independent Retirees Association complaining about the time given to nominate for the awards. They, like most groups, indicate that at least two months would have been a much more appropriate time frame for the awards. The ridiculously short time frame provided to administer the awards will invariably mean that older Australians are denied an opportunity to participate in this worthwhile program.

I had been seeking information on them for some months through estimates, but I got my letter in late July/early August like everybody else. I wrote to the minister following receipt of that letter, but I have not received a reply, nor any explanation as to why the timetable has been so curtailed.

It is even more concerning now that the government has announced another schemeâa Commonwealth government Senior Australian of the Year Award, which is a most worthwhile initiative. But again, it seems that this has been done with haste at the last minute and that an inappropriate time line has been set. From what I have seen in the press, the advertisements calling for nominations were placed in the national press only 10 days prior to the closure of nominations. Because of the time frame involved, there was not even a formal nomination form process; people had to cut out the ad in the paper and nominate on that because so little time was allowed for the process. On contacting the organisation running the award, it became quite clear that far too little time has been allowed to do the scheme proper justice. That is very disappointing, and the public deserve an explanation of why we have not got our act more together. If we are serious about recognising the contributions of older Australians, we must give them due respect, and the schemes that the government administers have to be promoted and organised in such a way as to allow the greatest possible participation.

The opposition is concerned that the offer we have made of a bipartisan approach to the International Year of Older Persons does not seem to have been accepted; we do not seem to have been involved in the year in any serious way. That is disappointing, but we will continue to try to make a positive contribution. It is important that I raise these concerns today. A lot of MPs have raised them with me, and I have had a lot of contact from constituents and aged care groups raising concern about some of these matters, and we need to give voice to them. I have been hesitant about raising these concerns because I do not want to be seen to be knocking the year or curtailing the efforts of the many good people who have taken a positive attitude to getting involved in the International Year of Older Persons. I, too, and all the other Labor members of parliament want to be positively involved, but we have to make sure we do not miss the opportunity through lack of organisation or lack of commitment to the year. We think there is still a chance to make the year a very worthwhile event and that a real push by the minister to get on with the job of making the year a success can be achieved. We are happy to give support to that, but we also support the view of ARPA and others when they say to the minister, `Get on with it.' We can do better and we should do better, and the Labor Party stands prepared to contribute to making sure that the International Year of Older Persons is a success.

answer.para: In the May budget the government forecast a moderation of growth from the very high growth that the Australian economy has achieved over the last couple of years. âMy question is directed to Senator Minchin, the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources. The emerging world market for magnesium presents real opportunities for Australia. The current value of that world market is about $1 billion per annumâabout 400,000 tonnesâand it is expected to grow by about a third over the next six years. One reason for that trend is the car industry increasingly using magnesium in its production of motor vehicles because it is a light, strong metal. This means that cars can be made much lighter and, therefore, more fuel efficient. I think this is one area where the increasing environmental trend to cleaner, more fuel efficient cars is actually having a very good spin-off for the Australian mining industry. We are poised to become a world leader in the supply of magnesium into these global markets for two reasons: firstly, we have quite significant deposits of magnesite, which is the raw material for magnesiumâin fact, in virtually every state of Australiaâand secondly, and even more importantly, and I think this shows the future for the mining industry, we have developed some very important technologies in Australia which will place us as a low cost, efficient supplier of magnesium to the world market.

The CSIRO has contributed its expertise and about $25 million over the past seven years to the development of this AMC project technology in a collaborative research joint venture. talk.start.para: âI move:

talk.start.para: âThis debate really does illustrate just how irrelevant the Labor Party has become in Australian politics. And today, contrasting with Senator Herron getting questions yesterday on the very old, we have had the very young; the child-care bean came out of the barrel. We listen constantly in this place to the scare campaigns that are directed at vulnerable members of the community who are unable, for one reason or another, to have a voice and speak for themselves.

I was interested to hear Senator Crowley say she is having phone calls from concerned people who say, `It's not like it was before.' Senator Crowley is right: it is not like it was before. talk.start.para: âThe Australian community has long woken up to the fact that it is not just a question of how much the government say something that makes it believable; it is worth while having a closer look at and analysing what they are actually saying. Despite the sanctimonious admonitions of the senators opposite, we have raised some issues in the Senate this afternoon of significant importance to the Australian community. Those issues relate to how families with children are coping with areas of child care that can be considered to be bordering on crisis. I am talking about the parents who come to the offices of members on this side of the chamber and say, `We cannot afford child care anymore. We are making decisions that affect the whole structure of our lives on the basis of the changes the coalition government have made to child care in this country.'

speech.para: Those changes are quite significant: a series of cuts across the three budgets delivered by the coalition government since they came to power, and the restructuring of the way child-care support is offered to parents so that there are now disincentives for families with young children to have two parents working. One of the more insidious impacts of these changes to child care is the numbers of young women and young couples who are making a decision to either delay having children or not have children at all because they cannot see a way of having a career or an opportunity to work and having children at the same time. It has taken only a short period of timeâ3Â½ years of a coalition governmentâfor such a significant shift in attitude to occur. Once upon a time in Australia, women right around this country felt that there was value in the equal opportunity they had to participate in the work force and have families at the same time.

The points raised in the chamber today are significant for two reasons. We are seeing a government pedantically trying to justify its continuing agenda with respect to child care. I do not believe the government will ever convince this community that what they have done to child care is, in fact, a good thing and is representative of progress in servicing the needs of families. In fact, it is the opposite. Attempts by the government to manipulate statistical data in the way that they have done with child care in Australia will only serve to emphasise the depths of deception that they are prepared to go to in presenting their specific agenda. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âHere we go again with more scare campaigns. On Monday it was the economy, yesterday it was aged care, and today it is child care. speech.para: That the Senate endorse the findings contained in paragraph 34 of the 78th report of the Committee of Privileges.
On 27 May 1999, the Senate referred the following matter to the Committee of Privileges:
Having regard to the documents provided by the Community Affairs References Committee in relation to the compilation and distribution of the Allars report:
(a) whether witnesses who gave evidence before the committee were injured in consequence of their evidence;
(b) whether the proceedings of the committee were misused to inflict harm upon witnesses before the committee;
(c) whether the proceedings of the committee were misrepresented; and
(d) whether there was an unauthorised publication of a document compiled for submission to the committee and submitted to the committee,
and whether any contempt of the Senate was committed in relation to these matters.

These questions were derived from a letter by the present Chair of the Community Affairs References Committee, Senator Crowley, to the President of the Senate. That committee was concerned about possible injury caused to witnesses before it and possible abuse of Senate proceedings, following the government's acceptance of one of the recommendations, contained in its report on the CJD settlement offer, that a review be undertaken of scientific evidence given to the committee.

When the review was completed and the resultant report delivered, the Department of Health and Aged Care published it widely within the CJD community. Certain persons, who had given evidence to the Community Affairs References Committee, were concerned about the review report's comments on their evidence, and sought that it be withdrawn. The department responded that the review report had been prepared specifically for the purpose of being presented to the community affairs committee, and was therefore covered by parliamentary privilege. The community affairs committee's primary con cern was that, in claiming the protection of privilege, the department may have misrepresented the proceedings by attempting to give protection to the review report.

The Committee of Privileges sought an explanation from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, the Hon. Dr Michael Wooldridge, as to the circumstances surrounding the publication of the review report. His response, which is quoted extensively in the report I have just tabled, has enabled the committee to make the following findings in relation to the terms of reference: (a) and (b) that no adjudication on these terms of reference is required; (c) no contempt of the Senate is involved; and (d) unauthorised publication of the review report occurred, but no contempt should be found. This report is long-awaited. In October 1997 the Senate referred the matter of the proposed new reactor to the Senate Economics References Committee for inquiry. During that time we have seen a number of events occur which impacted upon the finalisation of the report. Firstly, shortly after the committee started taking evidence, an EIS process was commenced into the proposed construction of the reactor. The committee felt that it was appropriate to await the outcome of that EIS process. Subsequently, the election occurred in October last year and the Senate committee had to be reconstituted.
