Following that, the committee took further evidence from interested groups and individuals in relation to the findings of that EIS, which has now lead to the committee issuing its report.

The committee has found that the government's decision to construct a new reactor was both premature and ill-considered. The appropriate starting point for considering this issue is to go back to the 1993 Research Reactor Review, often referred to as the McKinnon review, which was conducted by the previous Labor government. That committee looked at the issue of whether or not Australia would need a new reactor when the HIFAR reactor reached the end of its life and would need to be decommissioned in approximately the year 2003. The Research Reactor Review looked at a range of issues and found that it was not necessary to make a decision at that stage but that the issue should be revisited again in five years time. That brings us through to the present day. The Research Reactor Review committee at that time said:
If, at the end of a further period of about five years,
. a high level waste site has been firmly identified and work started on proving its suitability
. there is no evidence that spallation technology can economically offer as much as or more than a new reactor;
. there has been no practical initiation of a cyclotron anywhere worldwide to produce technetium-99m
. there is good evidence of strong and diverse applications of neutron scattering capability in Australian science, including many young scientists, and a complex of industrial uses
. the national interest remains a high priority
it would be appropriate to make a positive decision on a new reactor. The most suitable site would need to be identified.
I emphasise that last comment: `The most suitable site would need to be identified.' In particular, the review found:
If any of these onerous requirements is not met, either a negative decision, or a decision to delay further, would be indicated.
Further, in respect of logistics and siting, the review stated:

If a decision were to be made to construct a new reactor, it would not necessarily best be placed at Lucas Heights. An appropriate site would best be decided after exhaustive search, taking into account community views.

The decision made by the government was a political one. On the same day that it announced it would no longer proceed with its proposal to build an airport at Holsworthy, it announced that it would build a new reactor at Lucas Heights. Remembering the words of the Liberal Mayor of Sutherland Shire Council, Kevin Schreiber, he said he went to bed that night knowing that he would not have an airport in his shire but he would wake up with a new reactor. That was clearly a political decision.

In making that decision the government has ignored just about every one of the recommendations of the Research Reactor Review. Firstly, there has been no comprehensive examination of whether or not alternative technology, such as cyclotrons and spallation sources, and the importation of radioisotopes would be a better medium-term and long-term approach to adopt than spending some $300 million-plus on a single nuclear reactor. There simply has not been a proper exhaustive analysis of that. The committee took evidence on those issues and, whilst the committee is somewhat apprehensive that those technologies have advanced sufficiently, we believe that it would be appropriate for a proper independent public inquiry to be held to look at all of those issues and make a decision independent of government, and particularly independent of ANSTO and the nuclear industry which have a vested interest in having this facility built.

More importantly, the recommendation of the reactor review in 1993 was that no steps be taken for a new reactor to be built until a permanent site had been determined for storage of the high level waste currently stored at Lucas Heights and that work had commenced on that proposal. That has not occurred either. Whilst there is a proposal for the storage of low level wastes that are generally produced in a range of industrial arenas, as well as in hospitals and so on, and that material may well end up being stored at a proposed site in South Australia, there has been no decision by this government on where the waste from Lucas Heights should eventually be stored.

The minister is on record as saying that, because the material will be sent overseas to be reprocessed and brought back to Australia some years down the track, we do not need to make a decision on this just yet. That is not good enough. It is not good enough for the hundreds of thousands of people who now live in the Sutherland Shire and who face the prospect of another reactorâmaking three reactors on that siteâoperating for the next 40 years and producing more waste. Lucas Heights will continue to be the de facto nuclear waste dump in this country. In a country as modern as Australia, with all of the natural advantages that it has, it is ludicrous to suggest that a site that is within a couple of kilometres of thousands of people should continue to be a nuclear waste dump site. No decision has been made on that and, therefore, the McKinnon recommendation has been ignored.

Similarly, the government has ignored the recommendation that there be an exhaustive assessment of alternative sites. We know the reason. The reason for the government saying that the reactor should go to Lucas Heights is based upon cost. We acknowledge that it would be cheaper to put it at Lucas Heights. After all, that is where the existing infrastructure is. But that of itself should not be the be-all and end-all of this process of determining whereâif we have a nuclear reactorâit should be located.

The McKinnon review recommended that alternative sites should be looked at. When we questioned the government and ANSTO about that they said, `Yes, we have looked at alternative sites, but we can't tell you where they are because that is cabinet-in-confidence information.' Again, that is treating the people of the Sutherland Shire with contempt. I reject the argument that is advancedâthat simply because the reactor was present at Lucas Heights when it was a remote site 40 or 50 years ago, the new reactor should go there now and it is just bad luck for all those people who moved into that region afterwards and they have to cop the new reactor. I regard that as a crude, arrogant view to adopt. It is not the view that would be adopted, I would suggest, in regard to many other assessments of projects and their impact on the community. There is much more that I could say about this matter. We have recommended that, in accordance with what was recommended by Professor McKinnon, a full public inquiry should be conducted. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: âI rise to speak to the report of the Economics References Committee on the new reactor at Lucas Heights. The Australian Democrats support the findings and the recommendations of the majority report to which Senator Forshaw has referred. However, we have provided supplementary remarks which we believe go further; that is, we do not believe the recommendations contained in the report go far enough. Therefore, in our remarks we have added some suggestions.

speech.para: At the outset, I state very clearly for the record the Australian Democrats' clear and unequivocal opposition to the construction of a new nuclear reactor in this country. We do not believe that a new reactor has been justified on any of the grounds provided to the committee. We are quite outraged that the onus has been placed on the opponents of a new nuclear reactor to argue against its construction. What we should be doing instead is listening and waiting for the government to justify the extraordinary costs of all kinds that are associated with this proposed new reactor. Both the government, we believe, and the opposition have signed off on this new nuclear reactor, albeit acknowledging the opposition's concerns.

The government have made it clear that they are going to force this new reactor throughâit is not a replacement reactor; it is a new reactorâcontrary to broad community opposition, world opinion and the evidence that has been provided to the committee. The opposition is apparently concerned with the processes adopted by the government, but believes that a new reactor can be justified. The Australian Democrats do not believe that a new nuclear reactor in Australia can be justified. Even with the benefit of post Cold War hindsight, we must ask why our country is so heavily involved in the nuclear cycle and why this government seems to insist on some kind of expanding nuclear agenda for our country.

I will leave that debate and discussion for another time but I do want to draw attention to the history, because it seems that both the government and the opposition have failed to learn their lessons on this one. Around the world nuclear weapons stockpiles continue to grow. Nuclear waste is overflowing and problems of radioactivity have become a nightmare. For the residents of Lucas Heights and for the people of the Billa Kalina region in my home state of South Australia, and of course for the Australian population, I want to remind you that Australia already operates a high level nuclear waste dump in a suburb of our largest city. This government is now promoting the removal of this nuclear waste to a proposed dump on the land of the Arabunna people in my home state of South Australia. At this stage, I wish to pay special tribute to the Kupa Piti Kungka Tjuta Women's Group for their continued fight against a radioactive waste dump in their country.

In storage at Lucas Heights there are around 1,600 spent fuel rods, used in the HIFAR and the smaller MOATA reactors during the last 55 years. Various attempts to ship out these problems to various overseas places have, understandably, failed. We are still waiting for a solution to the actual waste problem. And here we are talking about yet another nuclear site in our nation. So it should come as no surprise to this parliament that Australians do not want nuclear waste stored in their backyards. Extending our waste problem with the construction of a new nuclear reactor is both outrageous and incredibly irresponsible.

In recommending against a new nuclear reactor we have paid particular attention to the justifications provided to the committee by the government, by DFAT and by ANSTO. The most insidious of the justifications advanced is that the construction of a new nuclear reactor is necessary to maintain Australia's national interest. The national interest argument begins with the assumption that Australia will actually lose its seat on the board of governors of the International Atomic Energy Agencyâthat is, if we are not engaged in some kind of nuclear program, which, of course, includes the operation of a nuclear reactor. We are asked to believe that Australia's position on the board of governors is being used to promote the interests of nonproliferation. I am not quite sure where to start in addressing the absurdity of that statement.

Firstly, it is doubtful that the International Atomic Energy Agency can be regarded as an appropriate forum in which to pursue nonproliferation and nuclear safeguards. The agency remains a promoter of nuclear technologies through dual-use projects such as nuclear reactors and through continuing involvement in the trade of nuclear materials. Secondly, it appears that Australia originally earned a seat on the board of governors of the agency through enormous involvement in the supply of raw nuclear materials to both the United Kingdom and the United States during the 1950s. In another brief history lesson, I remind Australians that much of this material returned to Australia in the form of nuclear weapons, tested in my home state of South Australia, with little understanding of the consequences at that time and necessitating expensive and dangerous cleanup operations.

Thirdly, Australia continues to promote nuclear technologies internationally through the export of uranium and, more insidiously, by supporting the United States' timetable and strategies in nonproliferation negotiations. Another thread of the national interest argu ment maintains that an Australian nuclear reactor provides us with the expertise in managing the nuclear fuel cycle. According to some witnesses before the committee, operation of a nuclear reactor provides Australia with technical expertise and credibility, which enhance our export trade in uranium. The Australian Democrats' position in relation to uranium mining is clear; we oppose the export of uranium outright and so this argument is quite offensive. It is inconceivable that the continued export of uranium can be reconciled with the interests of nonproliferation.

One witness before the committee asked a short but perceptive question which I believe cuts to the heart of this issue: `Is the new reactor and the work it supports part of the solution or part of the problem?' I await with great interest an answer to that question. I am certainly not holding my breath but I look forward to a response from government on that particular topic.

Nuclear medicine has been advanced as another justification for the new nuclear reactor. I am concerned that this justification is being used because nuclear medicine is being promoted as the acceptable face of nuclear science. Witnesses before the committee indicated that the production of radioisotopes for medical use was only a small part of the use of the existing reactor, although from some reports you would think it was much more than that.

Having considered the evidence, I agree with the suggestion of some witnesses that equivalent sums spent in other medical areas would bring about significantly greater benefits. These other areas include both diagnosis and treatment procedures. In fact, there is no requirement for radioisotopes to be produced in Australia for use in nuclear medicine. According to ANSTO, the existing HIFAR reactor at Lucas Heights is actually shut down for around three months each year, and there seems to be no crisis in our health system as a consequence of that shutdown. During these periods radioisotopes are imported from commercial producers in other parts of the world. These have been produced at reasonable prices and apparently with excellent reliability. The Australian Democrats have not been swayed by the limited evidence of either industrial use or environmental use of radioisotopes. Industrial use does not seem to be economically viable if the true costs of isotope production are to be met, and it is hard to imagine that the so-called environmental benefits of a new reactor could ever outweigh the environmental costs.

Although nuclear science research would certainly be more difficult without a new reactor, the opportunity costs involved in constructing the reactor are significant. It remains unbelievable that this government is promoting a new reactor at the cost of at least $300 million at a time when many other parts of our research sector, specifically scientific research communities, are starved of resources. It is also difficult to understand how a new nuclear reactor can be justified, even within the nuclear science community, when alternative nuclear technologies are showing promise and the construction of research reactors around the world has ceased.

The Australian Democrats do not support the construction of a new nuclear reactor. It cannot be justified on the grounds put forward to the committee in the form of evidence. The Australian Democrats will continue to oppose any further involvement by this country, and by this government in particular, in the nuclear fuel cycle.

talk.start.para: âIn the main, I support the comments of both the previous speakers, who have put forward a cogent argument to give the government cause to question its whole trajectory in regard to replacing the nuclear reactor at Lucas Heights, which is decrepit, with a new nuclear reactor which brings a great deal of concern not just to the local residents but to Australians as a whole. The answer to the question of where to dump the high level nuclear radioactive wastes has not been solved because there is no resolution to that. Senator Stott Despoja was just talking about the science at the Lucas Heights reactor establishment, which we might think is for the benefit of this country, but the one experiment that I know of that is going on there is an experiment to move towards laser enrichment of uranium for the purpose of making it cheaper to run nuclear reactors. And, incidentally, in the hands of anybody this technology would make it cheaper to make nuclear bombs.

speech.para: Why on earth is that science getting priority from this government? Is there no more constructive endeavour as far as the facility at Lucas Heights is concerned? I cannot see the responsibility in that. If it was aimed at pure medical research, then there would be a different attitude and I suspect the Australian public would have a different attitude to it. But it is not. By the way, that research is under licence to the United States. It is ultimately being eyed as a profit maker for those people around the world who are involved in a nuclear power industry, with spin-offs for nuclear weaponry, a matter which worries the whole world. We should not be involved in it. So I do not have faith in the simple assumption that we need this reactor, amongst other things, to promote science. There is good science and there is bad science and, from what I can see of it, there is at least a big measure of bad science going on at Lucas Heights.

The government needs to get that facility in order before it tries to convince the Australian Greens, at least, that we need this new reactor. As Senator Forshaw pointed out to the chamber just a while ago, the government is moving in a direction which fails the deliberations of parliamentarians and the public who have made submissions over the years to chart a different course. With that, I put the Australian Greens' position that nor are we in favour of the renewal of this reactor. We stand very solidly with the people of the Sutherland region, who have worked very hard to try to remove this insidious and invidious industry from their locality, and the people elsewhereâincluding in Senator Stott Despoja's home state, as she has saidâwho are concerned that they are going to be used as an outlet for a government that has no answer for the storage of nuclear waste.

I finally add: we have two nuclear waste ships approaching Australia's shores right now. They are going to sail south of Australia. They will come closest to Tasmania, then up the Tasman Sea between us and New Zealand on their way to Japan, with high level nuclear wastes, including plutonium. Despite all the assurances, I have been unable to get an answer from the Minister for the Environment and Heritage, Senator Hill, that there is any indemnity or insurance if the unthinkable happens and one of these ships runs into trouble and contaminates our region. With the Tasmanian economy at stakeâand that of Australia in generalâthe government will not even say where those ships are, though it knows.

talk.start.para: âI hope it doesn't end up in Sydney Harbour.

âExactly. Sydney Harbour is not beyond the reach of radioactivity released from anywhere in the vicinity. These ships will be coming past Sydney in the first fortnight of this month. In other words, they are in our region already. South Africa protested. Indonesia will not have them going through between Indonesia and Malaysia; nor will Malaysia. New Zealand does not want them in the region. This Senate has passed a motion of concern which was put forward by the Labor Party. But the Howard government, the same people who want to build this reactor, could not care less. In fact, they are in favour of those waste ships coming past because they want to feed into the same cycle. Call that acting in the national interest, if you will.

speech.para: I do not go along with this proposal. The Howard government have a lot of answering to do; they have a lot of homework to do. Australians would in the main feel much better if Australia joined New Zealand in taking a much more positive attitude towards the threat of nuclear weapons and helped the world move more rapidly towards getting rid of not only nuclear weapons but the nuclear cycle itself, which has been such a threat to life on this planet in this century.

talk.start.para: âWith the majority report that has been tabled today the Labor Party has shown that it is playing politics, or it has demonstrated its absolute weakness and its unfitness to govern because of its inability to make a decision. It is indeed playing politics with what is a very important issue for Australia and a very significant national facility. This whole inquiry into the replacement reactor for Lucas Heights was initiated in the lead-up to the last federal election by the opposition and by Senator Forshaw in particular as a purely political exercise. This was a blatant attempt by the opposition to scaremonger in the lead-up to the last federal election. In particular, it was an attempt to fabricate an issue in the electorate of Danna Vale in a vain attempt to bring about her defeat at the last election. Of course that strategy failed absolutely, because Danna Vale was returned in that electorate handsomely and with flying colours, so this strategy fell flat on its face. Now we see through this majority report that the Labor Party wants to attempt to keep this issue going for another three years in yet another vain attempt to crank it up as an issue in Danna Vale's electorate. So, as a political exercise, this has failed dismally for the Labor Party.

speech.para: Through this majority report we see that the Labor Party has again failed to make a decision on this issue. It failed to make a decision on a replacement reactor for Lucas Heights when it was in government, and now in opposition it is squibbing on making a decision on the replacement reactor. What the opposition wants to do is have yet another inquiry into the replacement reactor at Lucas Heights on top of all the inquiries that have already been conducted. We have had this Senate inquiryâthe report of which we are tabling today. We have had the RRR inquiry and we have had other assessments made by the government. It simply demonstrates the incapacity of the Labor Party to actually look at evidence, look at the need for this facility and make a decision. It wants to put it off, put it off and put it off again, as it did in government, by seeking more and more inquiries. As I say, that is partly a demonstration of its weakness as a party but it is also a demonstration of it playing politics on this issueâwanting to fabricate the issue and keep it running as long as it can.

We also heard from Senator Stott Despoja and Senator Brown on this report. They simply raised red herrings on the issue and perhaps an even greater level of scaremongering than Senator Forshaw. Senator Stott Despoja raised the issue of nuclear weapon stockpiles. Those stockpiles have absolutely nothing to do with the Lucas Heights reactor. The Lucas Heights reactor has nothing to do with nuclear weapons. It is a facility for scientific and medical research and nothing more, so that is simply a red herring and scaremongering on the part of Senator Stott Despoja. It shows how little attention she paid to the actual conduct of the inquiry and to the evidence presented to the committee. Senator Brown raised the issue of nuclear waste ships passing by Australiaâagain, absolutely nothing to do with a replacement reactor at Lucas Heights. It has no relevance to this issue whatsoever.

That is why Senator Gibson and I, as the government members of this committee, reject absolutely the majority report and indeed have produced a minority report which supports the decision made by the government to proceed with the construction of a replacement reactor for the now antiquated HIFAR reactor located at Lucas Heights. We believe that the case for constructing a replacement reactor without further delay is absolutely clear-cut. Unlike the oppositionâwhich I have already said are calling for a further inquiry on this issueâwe believe that the government has made the correct decision and ought to get on with construction of the facility without further delay. No useful purpose will be served by a further inquiry. No further information on this matter will be elicited by a further inquiry. Apart from the delay it would cause in constructing this much needed facility it would also be an absolute waste of taxpayers' money.

Lucas Heights is the only logical place to build a replacement reactor. It has been well established that the presence of the existing HIFAR reactor for 40 years has had absolutely no detrimental or adverse effect on the local community. The existing reactor has operated very safely, and of course the important thing to note is that the new replacement reactor, using the most up-to-date technology, will be an even safer facility than the reactor that is being replaced. So com munity safety will be improved. The old reactor has operated very safely and the replacement reactor will have improved safety margins over that. Independent studies have clearly shown that, even if there is an incident at the reactor, it is highly unlikely there would be any danger to the local community from such an incident. Indeed, driving on the roads in the shire of Sutherland poses a far greater riskâ

talk.start.para: âYou can't drive on the roads.

âEspecially when Senator Forshaw is on the roads, I would hasten to add. But, generally, driving on the roads in the Sutherland shire poses a much greater risk than will ever be posed by a replacement reactor at Lucas Heights.

speech.para: I draw to your attention the fact that even in this majority report the Labor Party are prepared to acknowledge the very considerable benefits associated with nuclear science in Australiaâbenefits for the whole community. Therefore, their position is completely illogical. They acknowledge the benefits of nuclear science and they acknowledge the benefits that a replacement reactor will bring but they still say, `Oh, no, let's have another inquiry. Let's delay the construction of this reactor even further.' In chapter 2 of their majority report there is a comprehensive examination of the significant benefits to medicine, industry and scientific research from the replacement reactor. These benefits are beyond reasonable dispute. Senator Gibson and I were persuaded, for example, by the evidence that virtually every Australian will receive some form of medical treatment during their lifetime involving reactor produced pharmaceuticals. If we delay further the construction of this much-needed facility, then Australia and Australians will be disadvantaged.

We acknowledge there is some community concern about the presence of nuclear waste at Lucas Heights, and in the debate earlier the issue of nuclear fuel rods was raised. But, again, we must recognise that the government has taken positive action to address this issue by the establishment of firm contracts to have spent fuel rods removed and reprocessed overseas and by the decision to establish a national waste repository in a remote part of South Australia, my state, which I support and which will take low- and intermediate-level waste only. Therefore, again, that waste repository poses absolutely no threat and no danger to those isolated communities in that remote part of South Australia.

In terms of the waste from Lucas Heights, we have firm contracts in place to deal with the spent fuel rods coming from that facility. So there is absolutely no argument in terms of the need for this facility. Alternative forms of technology simply do not measure up in what they can offer, both in their state of development and in their capacity to produce the requirements economically. The nuclear reactor will be able to do that. It will be of great benefit to science and to medicine in Australia and, through that, to the whole Australian community. There is no argument for further delay. This matter has been examined repeatedly and often enough. The evidence is there in favour of the establishment of the replacement reactor, and the government should get on and put it in place so that the facility is available for the benefit of all Australians.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebateinfo.title: Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund Committee

talk.start.para: âOn behalf of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on Native Title and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Land Fund, I present the 14th report of the committee, entitled Examination of annual reports for 1997-98 in fulfilment of the committee's duties pursuant to section 206(c) of the Native Title Act 1993 , together with the Hansard record of proceedings.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

talk.start.para: âI move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report examines the 1997-98 annual reports of the National Native Title Tribunal, the land fund and the Indigenous Land Corpo ration. The committee has now reported on the tribunal's first five annual reports and on the ILC's first four annual reports, because the ILC did not commence its work until 1 June 1995. The history of the committee's reporting on the annual reports is significant. With one exception, the committee has held public hearings each year to consider the annual reports, which it has a duty to examine.

At the outset, I wish to acknowledge the assistance that the tribunal and the ILC have given the committee through the public hearings. Although the committee would claim to have contributed to the understanding of the parliament and others through its examination of the annual reports transmitted by the tribunal and the ILC, the committee itself has been considerably informed by the advice received from the reporting authorities. In this regard, I would like to make particular mention of senior officers of each of those organisations who have been responsible for facilitating the committee's examination not only of the annual reports but also of their organisations' wider activities.

Justice Robert French was the tribunal's president from 2 May 1994 until 31 December 1998. Honourable senators will be aware of the contribution made by Justice French during that period of time. As only the second president of the tribunal, he was responsible for much of the work to establish its operations, and Justice French also made a significant impact on the provision of public information about the nature of the native title process, something which was very much needed in the wider community. In all of this Justice French was supported by the tribunal's second registrar, Ms Patricia Lane, who retired on 31 December 1997. The tribunal will have continued access to Ms Lane's expertise because she has been appointed as a part-time member of the tribunal for the next three years.

Two senior members of the ILC have also completed their terms: Mr David Ross, who was the inaugural chairperson, began his four-year term when the ILC commenced its business in June 1995; similarly, Mr Peter Yu has been the ILC's deputy chairperson in a part-time capacity. He was appointed until May 1999, when Mr Ross also retired. Both Mr Ross and Mr Yu have provided a good deal of evidence to the committee about the ILC's activities and, during Mr Ross's term of office, the ILC quite importantly approved the purchase of about 200 properties and divested about 30 of these to indigenous corporations. The committee has already officially wished these two men well for the future.

Turning to the committee's 14th report, I would like to mention the most significant matters to which attention has been given. With regard to the tribunal itself, the committee commented on the issues of impartiality, workload, amendments to the act and public information on the work of the tribunal. In its 13th report the committee noted that a tribunal member, Mr Sean Flood, had stood down from the tribunal following controversial remarks he made about government native title policy in a speech at the University of New South Wales. Mr Flood subsequently resigned from the tribunal in October 1997. At its public hearing on 30 March this year, the committee was reassured to hear the new president, Mr Graeme Neate, say that tribunal members must act in an impartial manner for as long as they hold office. The committee will continue to monitor the tribunal's impartiality.

The tribunal's workload has, similarly, been a matter of continuing concern to the committee. At the end of the 1997-98 reporting period, there was a total of 804 claimant applications lodged. `Future act' activity was also intense, with almost 4,000 notifications. This significant workload confronted the tribunal at a time when there had been a reduction in the number of tribunal members through retirement and resignation. The committee has expressed the view that the tribunal should not retain consultants to manage this workload but should provide advice to government so that an adequate complement of members can be made available.

With regard to amendments to the act, the committee was pleased to learn that, in the tribunal president's opinion, amendments passed in the Native Title Amendment Bill 1998 have provided new tools for more flexible and expeditious resolution of native title claims. For example, before the amendments were made to the act, the tribunal had relatively few statutory processes to deal with extra- and intra-indigenous disputes. As well, the committee has commended the tribunal for its efforts in disseminating information about native title in public education programs. The committee will continue to consult with those who may be affected by the lack of information to ensure that adequate and accurate information is available from authoritative sources.

The committee's 14th report similarly referred to substantive matters in regard to the ILC's 1997-98 annual report, and these include land management and operational challenges facing the ILC. In its 13th report the committee had expressed concern that its recommendation to the ILC to provide a comprehensive account of land under management had not been followed. It is pleasing to note that in the current annual report this suggestion has been adopted. In fact, appendix 4 of the ILC report details land management expenditure during 1997-98 on land held by the ILC as well as assistance provided to indigenous land holders. In addition, the committee has been able to confirm that the ILC was involved in the actual management of land purchased by the ILC in the 1996-97 period of time. We on the committee will continue to monitor these land management activities. Can I say that the ILC should be commended regarding its annual report for the way in which it described the operational challenges it faces.

I have heard it said that land prices have been artificially raised as a consequence of the ILC's apparent willingness to pay above the going market rate in its property purchases. Can I respond to these comments by quoting from the evidence given by Mr Murray Chapman, General Manager of the ILC, at our hearing on 25 March, when he said:
. . . because of the nature of the property market . . . it would be hard to get a handle on precisely who is getting the best of whom.
Mr Chapman went on to say that:
. . . anecdotal evidence suggests that the ILC is increasingly getting a reputation for not being easy to fool in property negotiations.
If there is firm evidence to support the claims of above value prices being paid, the committee would be very pleased to receive it.

I have also raised with Mr Ross the issue of the purchase of property to enable dispossessed urban Aboriginal families to also benefit from the funds of the ILC. Twice now, in indigenous roundtables that I have had with Aboriginal women in South Australia, this has been a consistent issue of concern as they face the prospect of life in rented accommodation because they are dispossessed and in the cities. This is to me a matter of great importance. I have spoken of it before in the chamber and I will be raising it with the new chair of the ILC, Ms Sharon Firebrace.

Another significant issue that the ILC has reported concerns obstacles confronting the purchase of grazing homestead freeholdings and grazing homestead perpetual leases in the state of Queensland, because under Queensland legislation these forms of tenure must be held by individuals and operated in effect as family farms. The ILC has been prevented from acquiring this land as a result of this constraint and, as such, those leases cannot be transferred to corporate ownership.

Before concluding, can I just note that the Australian National Audit Office has advised the committee that it has commenced a preliminary study to recommend to the Auditor-General that the ILC undergo a performance audit. If it proceeds the audit is expected to be completed for tabling in the parliament in June 2000. I expect that the report that I am tabling today will be of assistance in this process not only to the audit office but also to the tribunal and to all of those parties concerned with native title and the land fund. I commend the committee's 14th annual report to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

subdebate.1.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Heffernan) agreed to:
That this bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

talk.start.para: âI table a revised explanatory memorandum and move:

speech.para: That this bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard .
Leave granted.
The speech read as followsâ

Senators may recall that a small number of amendments were passed last year to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act 1967. These emerged as recommendations from a Review of Offshore Petroleum Legislation that commenced some time ago and was brought to finalisation in early 1998. At the time, the then Minister for Resources and Energy indicated further proposals emanating from the review might be presented to Parliament at a later date. The bill now before the Senate incorporates these proposals.

Over the years it has become evident that a number of provisions in the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act are no longer appropriate while others place unnecessary burdens on companies and government by way of reporting requirements and approvals. Seen against the backdrop of technological change in the petroleum industry and developments such as the opening up and growth of liquefied natural gas markets, there is a need to ensure that the act promotes the Government's objectives as set out in the 1998 Resources Policy Statement. The Government's vision is one of a competitive, innovative and growing petroleum sector operating in a streamlined legislative framework that offers high levels of certainty to stakeholders and contributes to rising national prosperity.

With this in mind, the proposed amendments to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Act aim to improve government administration and the efficiency of exploration for, and production of, petroleum resources. This is to be achieved without compromis ing operating, safety and environmental standards. The States, Northern Territory and the petroleum industry have been intensively involved in the Review and in drafting the amendments.
As there are no fundamental changes to the legislation, none of the changes could be called major, but I will now give some details about the more substantive ones.
I would mention four new provisions that the bill would insert in the act.

At the pre-exploration stage, where companies make competitive bids for exploration permits, an option is to be introduced whereby supplementary bids may be called as a tie-breaker for bids that are ranked equal. This will also create an incentive for each company to commit itself to more exploration work and expenditure.

Secondly, a new class of title known as an infrastructure licence is to be introduced to cater for at-sea operations that do not fall strictly within the ambit of current production or pipeline licences. One example is the licensing of offshore facilities for processing natural gas into products such as liquefied natural gas and methanol. Companies are reluctant to invest in processing plant unless they have security of title over the area in which it is to be located. Other examples are petroleum storage or offloading facilities, particularly where the facilities are not part of the production plant within a relevant production licence area.

The new infrastructure licence will also enable a company to remotely control some operations for the recovery of petroleum in an area when the petroleum is located in an adjacent production licence area. Thus, for example, companies will be able to connect subsea completions from the infrastructure licence area into the adjacent production licence area. Importantly, the existing requirements relating to good oilfield practices, including health, safety and environment protection, will equally apply to infrastructure licensees.

In addition, the infrastructure licence arrangements will enable continued use of facilities after petroleum production ceases from the production licence area in which the facilities are situated. For example, aged platforms could serve as a gathering and initial processing point for oil and gas produced from smaller adjacent facilities before being pipelined to an onshore processing plant.

Another new provision relates to information that companies are required to submit to the government and its protection so that trade secrets are not betrayed and the submitter's competitive position is not undermined. The existing safeguards involve gazettal of a notice to advise affected parties before any information that is deemed to be an interpretation of basic geological data can be released to third parties. The bill now introduces a streamlined system under which companies submitting information to the government will be able to declare at the time that they classify the information to be confidential or derivative. Unless the Designated Authority challenges this declaration within 30 days, the classification will stand and the information will be protected from release, permanently if it is confidential or for 5 years if it is derivative.

I would also mention the creation of a new offence, namely deliberately interfering with offshore petroleum installations or operations. This will carry a maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment, which will be equal to the strongest penalty provision in the act.

Turning to the provisions that will be repealed by the amendments, one of the most notable is the repeal of the Joint Authority's discretion to fix the number of blocks for renewals of exploration permits at 16.

The objective of the exploration permit system is to facilitate an optimal level of investment in petroleum exploration in offshore areas under the Commonwealth's jurisdiction. One of the mechanisms employed in the legislation to achieve this is a requirement that a permittee relinquish half the blocks covered by the permit at renewal, so that these relinquished areas may be released again for exploration by other companies. However, currently, at the Joint Authority's discretion, holders of exploration permits may retain up to 16 blocks where the halving process would otherwise result in fewer blocks being included in the renewed permit. This has become the norm and resulted in large areas being retained by companies for extended periods with a consequent reduction in areas becoming available for competitive bidding.

Accordingly, the discretionary minimum of 16 blocks for new permits is removed in the bill and the discretion for existing permits is to be removed after they have been renewed for the next permit term. Once a permit area has reduced to the point where the halving formula allows renewal over only 4 blocks, the permit will be renewable twice over those 4 blocks, instead of a 4 block renewal followed by a 2 block renewal. A one block permit will not be able to be renewed.

Another provision repealed is one relating to fragmentation constraints on areas covered by permits being renewed. At present, each exploration permit area must consist of aggregates of at least 16 blocks except where the total holding is less than 16 blocks. Moreover, each discrete area is to consist of blocks having a side in common with at least one other block. This concept is considered outdated because modern exploration techniques enable explorers to more accurately pin-point targets. Repeal of these constraints would enhance the attractiveness of permits as, at the permit renewal stage, the company could hold on to more targets it considered prospective.

The Government has also agreed to repeal the 21 year term of pipeline licences. The term is to be indefinite, but the pipeline licence will be able to be terminated if there has been no work on or use of the pipeline for a period of at least 5 years, subject to force majeure. This conforms with the change made last year to the term of production licences and will enhance security of tenure and thereby encourage investment in pipelines.

More generally, evolving technology is a factor behind a number of technical provisions being repealed with a view to incorporating them in regulations. The more technically prescriptive provisions are, the more quickly they tend to become outdated. There is therefore good sense in bringing such provisions into regulations, where they can more readily be amended than provisions of the act itself. The logistics of this require the provisions in question to be repealed only when the regulations are ready to come into effect. This is the reason why a subset of the amendments is to come into effect on a date to be fixed by proclamation rather than at Royal Assent.

Additionally, a number of minor machinery amendments are made to update the act to current legal and administrative practices. This is specifically in areas such as the removal of the need for companies to use approved forms, converting pecuniary penalties in the act to penalty units and deleting provisions relating to offences that are fully dealt with in the Crimes Act 1914.

There will be no net impact on the Commonwealth budget as a result of these changes. Annual licence fees payable to the Commonwealth will apply to pipeline licences and infrastructure licences with indefinite terms of effect as much as they would if the terms were limited. To this end, a consequential amendment is made to the Petroleum (Submerged Lands) Fees Act 1994 to ensure that the State and Territory costs of administering infrastructure licences are recovered from these fees in the same way as the costs of administering other titles. The overall effect of the amendments is likely to be reduced administrative costs for both government and industry.
I commend the bill to honourable senators.

talk.start.para: âThe committee is considering the Regional Forest Agreements Bill 1998 as amended. The question is that amendment No. 9 on sheet 1265 moved by Senator Brown be agreed to.

âThis amendment would mean that regional forest agreements would be terminated by illegal actions by state governments or their minions. If a court found that a state government which had signed off on a regional forest agreement had breached the state laws concerning forest management, forest industry practices or the conservation of the environment and heritage values in forestsâremembering that if they do that you cannot get the forest heritage backâthen the regional forest agreement would be deemed to have been terminated.

speech.para: Earlier in the day, Senator Troeth, by interjection on behalf of the government, disclaimed patriotic citizens who go into the forests peacefully to protect them and who are hauled before the courts because they are in breach of laws set up by state governments under the push by the woodchip corporations to prevent them from protesting. I challenge the government to support this amendment, because in upholding the laws we cannot have double standardsâat least one government senator agrees with me on that. Involved in this is a penalty if state laws are breached, the penalty being that the regional forest agreement would be terminated. Secondly, if the Commonwealth has given a month's notice of an intended termination to a state government then termination would follow. That is a power the Commonwealth needs to retain, seeing it is removing all its other powers under this legislation to protect Australia's forest heritage.

I mentioned the Goolengook heritage river area where illegal logging took place and hundreds of hectares of prime heritage forest in Victoria's East Gippsland were cut down under the direction of the authorities. If you follow the chain of command up you come to the Minister for Conservation and Land Management, Ms Marie Tehan, in Victoria. If you go further you come to the Premier of Victoria, Jeff Kennett. Under those circumstances of a massive breach of Victoria's own lawsâfound to be so, I might add, by the Supreme Court of Victoriaâwhat happened? Instead of there being any penalty for the woodchippers who carted those heritage forests off to Harris Daishowa's mill at Eden to be sent off to Japan, or any positive response to that from the Kennett government, they simply brought in retrospective laws to validate their illegal actions. Isn't it time we made a stand against that? Is that what we are going to continue to allow? This government will, because this government is not going to support these Greens amendments.

In the Otways in Victoria, very close to Senator Troeth's own base, there has been illegal logging in catchments and road reserves. In Victorian forest management areas there is evidence of logging levels exceeding legislated sustainable yieldsâthat would be illegalâand of logs being downgraded for saleâand that would be illegal. What has the government got to say about that? These are regional forest agreements which were to bring peace, security and order to the forests, but since they have been signed there have been gross illegal acts by the woodchip corporationsâand, at least in Victoria's case, by the government itselfâin places like East Gippsland and in my home state of Tasmania, which have led to the destruction of national estate and heritage river forests. As you know, Mr Temporary Chairman, once that happens, Australia has lost them foreverâthem and their wildlifeâand they do not come back. Does Mr Howard, who, as Prime Minister, signed off on those regional forest agreements, care a twig? What is his action to ensure that these illegal acts by woodchip corporations under the said control of Victorian Premier Jeff Kennett, in the case I have just outlined, stop?

Far from stopping it, the Howard government encourages it. Under this regional forest agreement this government says, `We have the example in Victoria and Tasmania'âand no doubt in Western Australia and in New South Walesâ`of illegal logging under the states' own laws. What is our reaction to that? We will hand the powers that we have to prevent that across to the same state governments.'

What an extraordinary thing to do, unless you understand that this government and Prime Minister Howard, through their actions, have shown that they do not care that the majority of Australians want that stopped. They do not care about the wildlife and forests of this country. I expect that they are not going to support this Greens amendment, which would give them the power to ensure that, if state governments continue to commit or allow illegal acts in the forests, the RFAs will be terminated.

If the government does not support this, let me never hear another government representative, including Senator Troeth, get up and criticise those Australians, not least the thousands of young Australians, who have gone out into the forests to protest about what is happening there. Let us have an end to this high-minded condemnation from on high of those young Australians. By opposing this motion, in effect the government is saying, `We know that the woodchip corporations and even state government instrumentalities can act illegally, and grossly so, involving millions of dollars worth of forests and their heritage, and we are actually going to abet that by giving more powers to the very people who do that.' I will remember this moment and this vote, and every time the government or anybody there wants to criticise citizens who want to protest in the forests as being law-breakers, I will remind them that they are in this process giving their tick to illegal acts in the forests of this country by the woodchip corporations and by state government instrumentalities.

talk.start.para: âIt will come as no surprise to Senator Brown that the government is opposing this amendment. I will remember this moment and this vote as yet another piece of evidence of the fact that Senator Brown will say and do anything to inject more uncertainty into this RFA legislation. This amendment is designed to create as much uncertainty as possible once an RFA is signed, and for that reason we are strenuously opposing it.

speech.para: The RFAs themselves provide the grounds on which RFAs may be terminated, and RFAs also provide a process to enable disputes to be resolved without recourse to termination. It is the overriding intention of the Commonwealth to comply with the terms of RFAs. However, this proposed amendment could lead to RFAs being terminated due to a minor technical breach of the RFA even though steps may have subsequently been taken to deal with that breach. As the amendment says, it allows the Commonwealth to terminate an RFA for any reason on just one month's notice. In relation to this point, again I will quote from the Office of General Counsel advice given on 10 August 1999, page 6, paragraph 24, which says:

The problem is that the deemed termination is expressed to take effect upon the giving of notice. In that case, what purpose does the notice serve and can it be regarded as notice of intended termination when the termination is already deemed to have occurred?

I would also like to take issue with Senator Brown on his calling upon thousands of young people going out into the forests to express their disapproval of this or any other government legislation. I would like to say to him that there are equally as many thousands of young people who depend on the timber industry for their jobs and for their parents' jobs, and they want to see this legislation go through.

In the past few days I received a media release from a community awareness campaign which is being organised in my home territory of western Victoria to highlight the economic, social and environmental benefits of an RFA and the need for a positive outcome for the timber industry. This was at Creswick in western Victoria and there were some 150 forestry workers there. Senator Brown may be interested in the fact that the timber industry injects $99 million into the Victorian economy and it employs almost 4,000 people across the western region. I am very proud to be associated with an industry which provides employment at regional levels at those levels of employment. Both as a person and as a Victorian senator, I do not see any reason why the timber industry should not be given that amount of direction and facilitation through a piece of Commonwealth legislation which will enable it to carry on its industry peacefully and with such good economic outcomes.

Why shouldn't that timber industry be able to employ the number of people that it does, and why shouldn't that timber industry be allowed to carry on a perfectly legitimate business without interference from people like Senator Brown? The only encouragement that Senator Brown has ever given the timber industry in Tasmania and in other places is to organise disruptive demonstrations, to throw himself at cars in an effort to impede the cause of progress and, through his activities and those of allied political parties like his, literally scare investment away from Tasmania. Senator Brown has quoted again and again falling levels of investment in Tasmania. All I can say is that, as far as the timber industry or any allied industry looking to put investment money into Tasmania is concerned, the sorts of activities that Senator Brown has indulged in for the last 10 to 15 years make Tasmania the last place in which timber industries or allied groups would put investment money.

The fact that some industries have continued to try to develop timber and allied industries in Tasmania speaks volumes for the sort of courage that they have. Senator Brown should be the last person to talk about being worried about jobs or about industry development because it is exactly this sort of amendment which shows that he holds totally the opposite view. He is determined to destroy the RFA legislation, which in the government's view provides exactly the sort of underpinning which the timber industry needs to develop in the future.

talk.start.para: âIf Senator Brown and Senator Troeth are both going to remember this day, I am going to remember this week and last week andâat the rate we are goingâwe will be remembering a few weeks in the future as well. One thing that I hope I do not have to remember and that I hope people will forget is the contents of a press release that Senator Brown has put out today, which he has entitled, `Forest industry chaos looms as Senate disallowance hangs over RFAs'. He says chaos in the logging industry and in federal parliament is looming `following the Senate's amendment of the Regional Forest Agreements Bill in Canberra today'. He goes on to refer to the fact that the disallowance provisions had been carried. I want to assure this chamber, the timber industry, all the state governments, the communities involved and indeed all the people of Australia that Senator Brown's claims are totally spurious. Furthermore, they demonstrate what his real agenda is.

speech.para: As I have indicated previously, we have moved to put in provisions which are designed to enable public and parliamentary scrutiny of regional forest agreements for the purpose of ensuring that there is not chaos and for the purpose of ensuring that RFAs reflect the goals of the national forest policy statement. The national forest policy statementâas I have said before and as I will say againâand what has occurred since then in developing RFAs has been a process about trying to take this industry out of the chaos that has existed over the years and to bring some stability and order into it. That is what we support, that is what this legislation supports and that is what our amendments do, in improving this legislation, to ensure that stability exists.

We are confident that, providing the state governments do their job, the federal government does its job and particularly if we can get a new minister for forestry, there will be in the future regional forest agreements that will bring stability and improvements to the industry. I reject the rubbish that Senator Brown has put out, but it does demonstrate his agenda.
His agenda is further demonstrated, of course, by the amendment that we are now dealing with, which the opposition will oppose. The amendment states:
(1) The Commonwealth is deemed to have terminated an RFA:

(a) if a court finds that a State government which is a party to the RFA has breached a State law concerning forest management, forest industry practices or the conservation of environment and heritage values in forests; or
(b) if it has given one month's notice of the intended termination to a State government which is a party to the RFA.

The first proposition, that an RFA is deemed to be terminated by the Commonwealth on the basis that there is a finding of a court in respect to what could well be a totally unrelated matterâthat is, a breach of state law concerning forest managementâis an absolute over-the-top proposition. It is a matter for the courts to deal with such breaches and, if necessary, impose penalties. There is no valid reason to make it a condition that any such finding that occurs automatically terminates an RFA. It is a nonsense proposition.

Secondly, the proposal that the mere giving of one month's notice of termination is sufficient to terminate an RFA is also an over-the-top proposition. It removes the very stability that the whole process is built uponâthat is, agreements being entered into after a lengthy and thorough process between state governments and the federal government. To then have a provision in Commonwealth legislation which says, `All the federal government has to do is give one month's notice and that's it,' is a preposterous proposition to put.

We are talking about agreements that are negotiated to provide security of the resource and of the native forest estate for the next 20 years and, it is intended, beyond those 20 years. Take the proposition that you can develop a regional forest agreement to deal with all of that, set programs in place, declare areas reserved, declare that areas are able to be logged, promote industry development and try and promote investment. Then you have to turn around and say, `Oh, yes, but the Commonwealth can decide, just on a whim and without any reasons being given whatsoever, that with one month's notice that agreement can be terminated.'

Frankly, that is just a nonsense. I would have thought that, by putting that proposition forward, any person holding themselves out to be a legislator or a member of a legislative body, as this parliament is, not only would not be doing their job but would be deliberately and wilfully trying to undermine the legislative processes of this parliament and of this country. We will not support the amendment.

talk.start.para: âThe question is that the amendment moved by Senator Brown be agreed to.

interjection.para: Question resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: âI will not go back to the response by Senator Troeth except to say that, although she cries crocodile tears about jobs in the industry, she said nothing when 400-plus jobs were lost out of the industry after the regional forest agreement was signed in Tasmania, and she will not say anything about the same thing happening in Victoria.
