subdebateinfo.title: Newcastle Disease: Central Coast of New South Wales

talk.start.para: âI suppose we will have to wait for another time to reply to Senator Knowles. I might have some stuff to drop on you tomorrow, Senator Knowles.

speech.para: What I want to talk about tonight is the outbreak of the Newcastle Disease on the Central Coast of New South Wales. In April of this year a virulent strain of the Newcastle Disease broke out at Mangrove Mountain on the Central Coast. It was the first time that this disease had occurred in Australia and it was the worst outbreak of what is called `emergency animal disease' in Australia's history. What occurred as a result of the outbreak was that two million chickens were killed, up to 9,000 emergency services personnel were used to bring the disease under control and, up to now, 70 farmers are facing financial ruin as a result of that emergency control.

The direct impact, of course, is on the federal seats of Robertson and Dobell where chicken growers and their families, employees of those chicken growers, contractors and the Central Coast economy have been affected significantly by this disease. In fact, it has been estimated that up to $20 million has been lost to the Central Coast economy. Many of the families affected have had no income at all for the last six months, and they have no prospect of any improvement in that situation over the next 12 months.

What is needed right now is action from the federal government. Initially, there was quick action by the government. It changed regulations to allow Newstart allowance to be collected by those people affected. An income test was applied, but there was no test applied to assets. However, farmers became ineligible for the allowance once the quarantine was lifted, even though it would take 16 weeks for chickens to regenerate so that income could be generated by those people. Some of the families are in desperate need and some assistance is still needed. In fact, these proud hardworking Australians up in the Central Coast are now in the situation where they are receiving food parcels from the Seventh Day Adventist Church and other charitable organisations. It has been estimated that it will take between two and four years before that industry recovers in that region, and still we are waiting for some sort of government assistance for these people who are affected.

The real issue at the moment is that there is a delay by the government in either rejecting or handling the application for exceptional circumstances. When Mr Vaile was the minister for agriculture, he encouraged the farmers to put in their applications for exceptional circumstances, and in fact they have since made detailed and comprehensive submissions, containing extensive data, to the new minister, Mr Truss. However, there is no expectation of determination on this application until sometime next year. In that period, farmers and their families are going to be in dire straits.

The exceptional circumstances conditions are three: the disaster has to be rare, unforeseen and severe. It is quite rare that this strain was able to mutate as spontaneously as it did; it is unforeseen in that it is the first time that it has occurred in Australia; and it is severeâas I said, $20 million is certainly a big bite of the Central Coast economy. There is ample evidence that the guidelines that are currently applied for exceptional circumstances are inappropriate in this case. The guidelines were created for crops which would be affected by drought, and under the guidelines the disaster must exist for a period of over 12 months. As such, a number of people become ineligible for any assistance along those lines. The government has recommended that people may wish to apply to the Farm Family Restart Scheme, but to qualify for this you must have been a farmer for two years. In that area, where there is a bit of a turnover, there are a number of people who will not be eligible.

We have a situation where there is a delay in the exceptional circumstances applicationâwhether it is going to get ticked off or notâand there are a number of families who are not eligible to apply to the Farm Family Restart Scheme. A number of these farmers have large mortgages. The banks have deferred the mortgages but they still have to pay interest. The people may be looking at bank ruptcy unless they can get some assistance from the government. A dollar spent now is a dollar that we do not need to spend down the track, because if we do not spend it now the damage will be done.

I would like to call upon the minister, Mr Truss, to go up to the Central Coast and talk to these hardworking, proud Australians who have been affected by something outside their control. I would like him to look them in the eye, look at their difficulties, look at how they are struggling to surviveâthese proud people who are actually taking food parcelsâand listen to what they have to say. Give them help. I know that, if Labor were in power, we would help.

talk.start.para: âSenator Hogg, I would like to express my appreciation to you for taking the chair to enable me to make this presentation tonight. I do appreciate it.

speech.para: There is a rather large predicament right now in my home state of Tasmania. On the surface, it would appear that three russet burbank potatoes, part of a small consignment from Tasmania to Western Australia, have been identified as possibly carrying the exotic disease ring rot. The potatoes came from one or perhaps two properties on the north-west coastâno-one is quite sure, because the bins carrying potatoes from one farm to another were topped up with potatoes from bins sourced from another farm.

Two properties have been quarantined and a large, imposing sign at the entrance of both farms reads: `Commonwealth of Australia, Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, Quarantine Area, No Admission without Permission, by Order, Chief Quarantine Officer.' Like an infectious diseases section of a hospital, no-one can enter or leave without notifying an authorised person. The farmers are even limited in access to their own properties, and further harvesting of potatoes still in the ground is on hold. The farmers are quite rightly shocked, bewildered and a little embarrassed that their properties have been locked, isolated and identified as perhapsâand I emphasise `perhaps'âcarrying the disease.

The disease ring rot has previously been found in some parts of Europe and America but never before in Australia. I would like to point out that potatoes dug out of wet ground often carry a ring around their skin, but they have never been suspected of contamination with ring rot. Samples of potatoes from the farms have been sent to Western Australia, Queensland and Hobart for testing, but pathologists have been unable to find the disease in any of the samples that have been tested. Extractions from the potatoes allegedlyâI emphasise `allegedly'âcarrying the very slow growing disease are currently growing on agar in an attempt to further the investigation, and DNA has been brought in from Canada to determine whose potato is hosting the symptoms, or, indeed, if any are. It is hoped to have colonies separated very soon so that the mystery can be solved. However, the pathologists in Hobart submit that the symptoms just do not ring true with bacterial ring rot.

Some of you may recallâTasmanian senators certainly willâthat Simplot recently closed its potato processing plant in Western Australia to concentrate its total activities in Tasmania. The tonnage is significant. No doubt there are many disgruntled farmers, packers and wholesalers in Western Australia who have been hurt by this decision and, in their own peculiar way, would see this stunt as `pretty good retribution'. In fact, I hear that it's all a bit of a joke in certain sections of Western Australia!

The industry in Tasmania is asking a lot of questions. They are not happy about what has happened, and rightly so. They understand that Quarantine must do its job. They respect that and ultimately want to be cleared of this alleged curse that has been temporarily bestowed upon them. However, the industry's major concern is that personnel in Western Australia pressed a very large panic button before obtaining more sound or even clear evidenceâa very large panic button that smacks of sour grapes or, should I say, rotten potatoes.

The insult commenced with Western Australian authorities and importers, in the month prior to their `great find', being unusually strict with certification and holding up the smooth flow of documentation whenever possible. No, fellow senators, this is not a case of bacterial ring rot in Tasmanian potatoes; it is a case of Western Australian farmers, packers, wholesalers and those in authority playing fast and loose with the very sound reputation of the Tasmanian potato industry. They are being bad sports. They are seeking retribution because something was taken away from them and given to someone else. They may think it's a joke, but actually we may have the last laugh.

The New Zealand fire blight issue comes to mind and I would have thought better of certain sections in Western Australia. They obviously do not know about AQIS in Canberra dealing with the rest of the world, seeking disease free status for export of our potatoes to many countriesâa disease free status that does not recognise that Bass Strait exists. Indeed, should they wish to export, they may wish they had never started this whole sorry episode from Western Australia.

Tasmanian farmers are conscientious, they are straight down the line. Their product quality management is very good, and I notice Senator Denman from Tasmania is nodding. I feel overwhelmingly a great sense of regret that our farmers, especially our potato growers, have been treated in this shabby way. Indeed, it may well end up being a `hot potato' for those who seek to denigrate the Tasmanian potato industry.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 31 March 1999:

question.para: (1) In undertaking normal value investigations overseas, what specific steps, in addition to the examination of so-called audited accounts by the Australian Customs Service (ACS), are taken to check the veracity of an exporters claim.
(2) Do such steps include reference to third parties and/or independent and credible trade and industry sources; if so, what specific examples of such references can the ACS provide; if not, why not.
(3) Is the ACS aware of the corruption perception index (CPI) and its purpose to provide data on perceptions of corruption within countries by national surveys.

(4) Are any allowances and/or adjustments made to quantify the reliability of audited accounts, which are supplied by exporters from countries which may suffer from `crony capitalism' and/or corruption.

(5) Given that on the 1998 CPI Indonesia scored the sixth lowest of the 100 countries ranked and Australian paper producers contend it has a high level of corruption, how has the ACS made allowance for this in its most recent inquiries in that country; if no allowance has been made, why not.
(6) Does the ACS have any rules or by-laws in place which govern the conduct of its officers who undertake overseas investigations.

(7) Are ACS officers cautioned about the essential need for them to remain at arm's length from former colleagues who may represent the interests of foreign exporters from time to time as consultants and/or lobbyists.
(8) Is it regarded as appropriate behaviour and acceptable practice for ACS officers to rely on the statements of any such former colleagues in such circumstances.

(9) What checks and balances does the ACS have in place to make allowance for any undue influence of an overseas investigation report by such a consultant/lobbyist; if no checks and balances are in place, why not.

(10) If checks are in place, how does the ACS explain the comments and words of appreciation for a former officer, now a consultant, which appear in the public file report of the officer who conducted the overseas inquiries in Indonesia for the coated papers dumping inquiry.

(11) In its consideration of `normal values' in overseas country investigations, how does the ACS determine the question of `normalcy' when the country in question is markedly disturbed by economic, political or social crisis with resultant impact on local markets from lack of demand and excess manufacturing capacity.
(12) Does the ACS make use of weighted averages in such circumstances.

(13) If weighted averages are applied, how can such use adequately assess the impact of extreme conditions such as the following, which, in the case of Indonesia, are asserted to exist by Australian paper interests: (a) exchange rates, which are known to fluctuate by as much as 26 per cent in a single day and regularly move by more than 10 per cent in either way on a weekly basis; (b) extreme volatility in currency movements with the currency declining to a small percentage of its original value; (c) inflation rates with volatile movements as much as plus 8 per cent in a month, then negative; (d) interest rates as high as 50 per cent per annum; (e) collapse of the banking systems with 60 to 80 per cent of non-performing loans; (f) technical insolvency of many of the country's enterprises; and (g) artificial support of the country's currency by substantial foreign aid, including significant funding by the International Monetary Fund.
(14) Do any, or all of the circumstances in (13) warrant the use of a surrogate country in order to establish `normal values'; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: In addition to a company's audited accounts Customs relies upon verification against management accounts, source documents, ie invoices, payment advices, etc and other internal company records;

(2) Where considered necessary Customs may resort to information provided by other sources as a means to check the veracity of the exporters claims or where the exporter declines to provide information or is unable to provide certain information. In the case of A4 copy paper pulp prices were compared against those to an unrelated third party and comments contained in a company research paper by a reputable broking firm.
(3) Customs is aware of the Corruption Perception Index as a result of a submission by Australian Paper in the context of the revocation inquiry involving A4 copy paper from Indonesia.

(4) No. Australia's legislation and World Trade Organisation (WTO) Anti-Dumping Agreement only recognise adjustments to prices where it affects price comparability. Further, Australia's legislation and the WTO Anti-Dumping Agreement require the use of the exporter's records where they are kept in accordance with generally accepted accounting principles in the exporting country.

(5) Customs has not made any allowance. Indonesia's ranking on the corruption perception index and Australian paper producers contentions as to the high level of corruption were not relevant as Customs was satisfied that such factors did not impact upon price comparability. No evidence of corruption affecting sales of A4 copy paper by Tjiwi Kimia was presented by the Australian industry.

(6) There are no regulations specific to undertaking overseas investigations. Customs officers are bound by the APS Code of Conduct as detailed in the Public Service Regulations (AmendmentâInterim Reforms) 1998. Regulation 5âThe APS Values and Regulation 7âThe APS Code of Conduct are particularly relevant.
(7) As for (6).
(8) In determination of normal values Customs officers do not rely upon statements by consultants, such determinations are based upon evidence.

(9) The result of overseas investigations "the normal value report" is subject of scrutiny and assessment by other officers including senior officers to ensure that the recommendations are supported by the facts.
(10) The report referred to contains the following statement, "Tjiwi Kimia, together with their consultant, cooperated fully with Customs and met most requests for copies of documents etc".

All normal value reports contain a section on Cooperation and Confidentiality. The visiting officers are required to give an assessment of the level of cooperation provided by the exporter. The assessment may have implications for how the information collected is assessed and the level of any measures that may be imposed.

(11) `Normalcy' is not a term used in the relevant legislation and therefore is not a consider ation in determining normal values. Where there is a situation in the market of the exporting country which renders domestic sales as unsuitable both Australia's legislation and the WTO Anti-Dumping Agreement provide alternative methods being sales to third countries or costs plus profit.
(12) Depending on the particular circumstances of an investigation weighted averages may be the most appropriate means to determine normal values.

(13) The application of the weighted average method to determine a normal value will adequately assess the impact of the extreme economic factors referred to if those factors effect either domestic selling prices or cost.

(14) The circumstances referred to in (13), per se, do not authorise recourse to surrogate information. The Minister could only contemplate the use of surrogate information if satisfied that sufficient information had not been provided or was not available to enable normal values to be determined by reference to either third country sales or costs plus profit.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: (1) Was National Jet Systems awarded a contract in 1994 to provide aerial surveillance capacity to Coastwatch for a 9-year period at a cost of $300 million.
(2) What is the current annual cost of the contract.

(3) What performance did the contract require of National Jet Systems in terms of providing: (a) total flying hours per annum; (b) equivalent surface area to be covered per annum; (c) average availability of aircraft per month; and (d) average systems malfunction per sortie.
(4) Have any alterations to that contract been agreed to between 1994 and before June 1999; if so (a) what was the nature of the alteration; and (b) what change(s) in performance were specified.

(5) With reference to recommendation 8 of the Coastal Surveillance Task Force; what will be the contract specifications for the two additional aircraft and instrument flight rules rated helicopter, in terms of (a) total flying hours per annum; (b) equivalent surface area to be covered per annum; (c) average availability of aircraft per month; and (d) average systems malfunction per sortie.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(3) (a) Based on the normal rates of effort specified in the Coastwatch contract, the contractor is required to deliver 14 295 hours of flying across its fleet of 13 aircraft.

(b) There are no equivalent surface area coverage specifications in the contract. Whilst it is possible to derive a theoretical potential maximum area of coverage per annum, achievement of this figure is influenced by a range of factors, not least of which are the weather conditions impacting upon sensor performance and aircraft endurance.

(c) The contract does not specify the average availability of aircraft per month. It does provide that the contractor is allowed three days per 100 hours of operation per aircraft for scheduled maintenance. Additionally, the contract stipulates a comprehensive performance based regime which uses a weighted matrix covering nine separate performance factors, one of which is the availability of aircraft, to derive a performance index. This index is used to calculate levels of payment to the contractor.
(d) Systems malfunction per sortie is not a performance bench mark. See also remarks at 3(c) above relating to the performance reporting regime.
(4) Yes. Contract variations that have applied since initial contract signature were formally signed into effect in February 1999.

(a) The mix of Aircrew allocated to particular aircraft, and their geographic basing was adjusted to reflect operational requirements. Maximum continued Rate of Effort (ROE) was adjusted to reflect CASA Aircrew duty cycle regulations.
(b) There was no change to performance requirements contained in the contract arising from the amendments signed into effect in February 1999.
(5) (a) For the two additional Dash 8 aircraft, 4000 hours; for the helicopter, 500 hours.
(b) See 3(b) above.

(c) In addition to existing performance measurements (see 3(c) above) which ensure that the contracted number of flying hours are delivered, additional performance requirements have been introduced for individual aircraft types and mission-critical equipment and radar.
(d) See 3(d) above.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: (1) During the 1997-98 financial year was approval given to Coastwatch to replace its information technology (IT) systems on the grounds of obsolescence and year 2000 compliance; if so: (a) what were the functions approved for the new IT system; (b) what was the cost of the approved system; and; (c) when was the new system implemented.

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(a) The functions of the system are to provide surveillance management tools for flight planning, briefing, reporting and analysis.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: With reference to recommendation 9 of the 18 recommendations presented to the Government by the Prime Minister's Coastal Surveillance Task Force:
(1) What functions, additional to those approved for Coastwatch information technology in the 1997-98 financial year, are to be added by virtue of the creation of a national surveillance centre.
(2) What is the estimated cost of the additional functions.
(3) When will the additional functions become operational.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The National Surveillance Centre (NSC) will provide improved internal capacity to analyse information received from agencies and enhanced electronic communications links, including with State agencies.
(2) The total cost over four years will be in the order of $20 million.

(3) Detailed specifications for the NSC are yet to be prepared and an operational date has not been set. However, as with all the Task Force's recommendations, it will be progressed as a matter of priority.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: (1) In the 1997-98 financial year, did the Intelligence Branch of the Australian Customs Service receive funding to improve its ability to securely exchange information with other Commonwealth law enforcement agencies; if so: (a) what were the functions approved for the systems; (b) what was the cost of the approved systems; and (c) when did the new systems become operational.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. The funding was for use by the National Crime Authority, Customs and the Australian Federal Police as part of the National Illicit Drugs Strategy (NIDS) Information Technology initiative. The Intelligence Branch, within Customs, was appointed to administer the funding on behalf of the other agencies.
(a) The functions were to:
(i) Provide secure data interchange for intelligence and operational information between operational law enforcement agencies.
(ii) Provide law enforcement agencies with secure access to a range of databases for analytical and investigative purposes.
(b) $4.9m setup, $4.3 ongoing.
(c) The current status is:
(i) AFP, Customs and NCA have been connected to the Highly Protected (HP) environment of the Secure Gateway Environment (SGE).

(ii) The implementation of a secure e-mail infrastructure between AFP, NCA, Customs and Austrac is under development. Implementation and completion of this functionality is expected in the financial year 99/00.
(iii) ACS and NCA access to the AFP's PROMIS database commenced in mid January 1999.

(iv) The development of a data upload facility from the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence (ABCI) ACID database to the AFP PROMIS database is expected to be completed in the 99/00 financial year.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: With reference to recommendation 9 of the 18 recommendations presented to the Government by the Prime Minister's Coastal Surveillance Task Force:
(1) What use will be made by the national surveillance centre (NSC) of Coastwatch of the improved communications links for Intelligence Branch.
(2) What additional communications functions are to be provided for the Coastwatch NSC; (b) what will be the cost of these systems; and (c) when will they become operational.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The communications links to be established for the NSC will complement those being implemented for the Intelligence Branch. The NSC will have access to relevant material transmitted over the Intelligence Branch links.

(2) (a) The National Surveillance Centre (NSC) will provide enhanced electronic communications links, including with State agencies and an internal capacity to analyse information received from agencies.
(b) The cost of the supporting infrastructure for the NSC including computer and communications systems over four years will be of the order of $11.5 million.

(c) Detailed specifications for the NSC are yet to be prepared and an operational date has not been set. However, as with all the Task Force's recommendations, it will be progressed as a matter of priority.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 2 July 1999:

question.para: (1) What was the relationship of the intelligence function of the national surveillance centre (NSC) to the Intelligence Branch of Australian Customs Service, in particular, will functions of Intelligence Branch be transferred to the NSC; if so: (a) what functions and what numbers of staff will be transferred; (b) what additional staff is to be recruited for the analytical function of NSC; and (c) what is the estimated annual cost of these staff.

talk.start.para: âThe answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

answer.para: Customs' Intelligence branch is responsible for strategic intelligence and intelligence liaison. The NSC will be responsible for tactical intelligence as it relates to the surveillance function. The Intelligence branch will continue to provide intelligence support to the NSC as required. Both Coastwatch and the Intelligence branch will be represented on the Information Oversight Committee. It is not intended that there be any transfer of staff or functions from Intelligence branch to Coastwatch.
(a) N/A
(b) Funding was approved for 11 positions for the NSC of which 9 will be for the analytical function
(c) $1.3 million for the 11 positions mentioned in (b).
